b'I have not actually observed the corruption
column8:
but an deducing this from the 
function behavior.

We currently download and install the feature files even if they already exist. 
The download part I am OK with
column9: but the install is a potential timebomb. I have \nnoticed that when we install nested features
column10: the feature files for feature 1 \nare installed before we start downloading files for feature 2. If the user \ncancels the operation
column11: feature 1 is left in the feature9999999.xml state. If \nthis was a feature that already existed prior to the install
column12:
we just blew it 
away.


Som we can download feature jar for features that are already installe (no 
harm) but we MUST NOT actually overwrite files for an existing feature (ie. we 
skip the install copy step for the feature files and only install diffed 
plugins)'

column7: b"DESIGN CHANGE: from go/nogo discussions\n\nWhen installing/ cleaning up
column8:
we currently take care to process the features 
and plugins in an order that never results in broken reference structures (eg. 
features referencing missing included features or missing plugins. The original 
thought was not to create broken structures. The downside of this approach is 
that we may end up with unmanaged plugins being included at runtime
column9: and \ninadvertently be executing by the time we want to redo the failed install
column10:
for 
example. This would likely cause the install to fail (eg. open plugin .jar).

The alternative strategy is to reverse the processing order. This would 
potentially leave broken features
column11:
but we would never end up with unmanaged 
plugins. The broken features could then be fixed by re-installing/ updating 
them.

To do this
column12:
install would need to do the pass-2 rename top-down (pass-1 can 
stay as is). 

Cleanup (after failure
column13:
[Cancel]) would need to be deleting bottom-up (bu NEVER 
anything we did not actually install in the failed opreation). Need to discuss 
this one to make sure we are in synch.

Also
column14: when poofing up the models
column15: we'd need to tolerate missing includes the \nway we tolerate missing plugins (ie. results in parent not being happy)"

column7: b"In our product (call it OurProd)
column8: we have many features that are not installed \noff of the install CD. Some of these features are optional
column9: and some
column10: due to \nlicensing issues with other companies
column11: are not allowed to be on the install CD \nat all. Our problem comes in the case where is installed as an extension into \nanother product(s)
column12: say Prod1 and/or Prod2. Under the current mechanism
column13: any \nfeatures that are laid down with the native installer will get update \nproperly
column14: but any features that are brought down with the Install/Update manager \nwill end up with the features of the product that was running at the time. These \nfeatures are a part of OurProd
column15:
not the product that is currently running. The 
user found out about them because our 'base' OurProd features installed the 
discovery URL's. We need a mechanism to allow a feature to say where it belongs. 
In the case of OurProd
column16:
we know that we will have our base features installed. I 
would like any other 'optional' features we have to be able to say that they 
want to be installed with the 'base' feature/plugin.

If this is left as it is now
column17: we can end up in the scenario where OurProd is \nextended into 2 or more products. If the user updates any existing OurProd \nfeatures
column18: these update will be available across all the products we were  \nextended into. On the other hand
column19: any new OurProd features that are downloaded
column20: \nwill be put in with the product we are running
column21:
even though they are OurProd 
features. Now we have the case where the product is 'polluted' with our OurProd 
feature. As well the other product(s) we are extended into will not see these 
features. This is now inconsistent with the experience of updating an existing 
feature in an extension."

column7: b'The update manager uses default Java I/O support to copy files. This seems to \ncreate all files with rw- permissions. On some systems shared libraries need x \n(execute). Having w in a shared install is also a problem.'

b'It should be possible for a product to provide a root feature that bundles 
together many features and yet still allow those contained features to be 
separately updated. 

Currently the orthogonal issues of how to update
column8:
vs. how to bundle have 
incorrectly been tied together.

This allows the feature to look like a product
column9: yet still allow its bundled \nelements to be updated. This is also important in the product upgrade scenarios.'

column7:
b'If a higher level feature wants to include a feature below that may be optional 
it has no way to do this. It would require two flavours of higher level 
feature \xe2\x80\x93 one with the lower optional feature and one without. This ripples all 
the way up.'

b"Eclipse R2.0 

We are using the Eclipse feature support for distributing common plugins to 
developers workstation. For example:

feature_0.0.1
  plugina_1.0.5
  pluginb_2.0.3

feature_0.0.2
  pluginA_1.0.5
  pluginB_2.0.4

After updating from feature_0.0.1 to feature_0.0.2
column8:
pluginA has been disabled 
(indicated in the feature's status). The reason seems to be the fact that the 
same plugin version is included in two different versions of the feature 
(manually removing the old feature version from the installations resolves the 
problem) 

Is there currently any workaround for this problem?"

column7: b'With our native installer
column8: we are laying down our base features. These features\nalso have install handlers to complete their work. According to the update team
column9: \non the first time we run
column10: if we use the -initialize switch
column11: the install handlers\nshould all be run with the completeConfigure method be called. This is not\nhappenning. When we run with -initialize
column12: our features install handlers are not\nbeing run'

b"Scenario:

1) Add a bookmark to http://dev.eclipse.org/viewcvs/index.cgi/%7Echeckout%
7E/platform-update-home/optionalSite/
2) Expand 'Products' and select 'Root 1.0.0'.
3) Install it as-is (with all optional features)
4) Restart. Install e-fix e334. Restart.
5) Verify that the configuration is correct and that XYZBogus 1.0.0 includes 
XYZ 1.0.0.e334 and shows up arrow.

6) Start Eclipse WITH A NEW (CLEAN) WORKSPACE. Check the configuration. XYZ 
1.0.0 shows up as an orphaned root feature.

Expectation: only one version of each feature should be configured by the 
reconciler. It should resolve all the included features using the best match 
and ensure that all other versions are not configured.

This problem happens on both 2.0.2 and 2.1 code base. It blocks both branch 
updates and e-fix updates (essentially all updates where only branches of the 
feature tree have been upgraded)."
b'After installing a patch/efix
column8:
attempting to start against a different 
previously existing workspace shows orphaned features with warnings after 
applying pending changes.

Consider this very simple scenario:
Feature 'master' includes Feature 'ftrA'.  Both are at version 1.0.0.
An e-fix called 'fix1' is created to patch ftrA.  It has the following 
feature.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<feature id="fix1" image="wsFeatUpdate.jpg"
    label="%featureName" provider-name="abc" version="1.0.0"
    colocation-affinity="RootFeature">
    <description>fix1 will install FeatureA version 1.0.0.1</description>
    <license url="%licenseURL">This is for test purposes</license>
    <includes id="ftrA" match="equivalent" version="1.0.0.1"/>
    <requires>
        <import feature="master" version="1.0.0" patch="true"/>
    </requires>
    <plugin id="fix1" version="1.0.0"/>
</feature>

To reproduce the problem:
1) Install Eclipse/Workbench 2.0.3
2) Add master and ftrA along with their attribution plugins
3) Start the workbench againt a fresh workspace
      eclipse -data ws1
4) Exit and start again against a 2nd fresh workspace
      eclipse -data ws2
5) Install the "fix1" efix while attached to ws2
column9: and restart when prompted.  \nNotice that it installed cleanly. No warnings in your update manager \ncongifuation.  It shows the fix1 feature and master as the top level features
column10:
as expected.
6) Exit and start against the first workspace again:
      eclipse -data ws1
7) It detects the pending changes. Say Yes to apply them
column11:
and allow it to 
restart when prompted.  The congifuration now shows an orphaned ftrA at version 
1.0.0 with a warning. 

The warning complains that ftrA version 1.0.0 expected to find plugin 'ftrA' 
version 1.0.0
column12:
but version 1.0.0.1 was found instead.

Our biggest concern is that this state could leave the workspace in a state 
where future fixes couldn't be applied safely.'

column7: b'When a workspace that has been created by 2.0.3
column8: is opened using 2.0.2 that \nhappens to have the same installation directory
column9: problems occur.  In the case\nof a productized version of Eclipse
column10:
the effect is that the main product
feature (from the product based on 2.0.2) is disabled.

The workarounds available are (each of which cause a full reconciliation):
1)  to make sure 2 install directories are different
2)  remove the .metadata/.config directory from the workspace
3)  change the id of the product feature

A testcase has been provided to Christophe 
(not included here since it contains WebSphere Studio code).'

column7: b'getItems should only return root items...'
b"This bug occurs due to the selection not getting cleared/checked internally prior to a submethod call is made.\n\nTo reproduce
column8: simply follow this: \n\n1. Have some items in a table
column9: select an item (or a cell)\n2. Call removeAll() on the table through an action or menu
column10:
etc.
(at this point the selection is still in memory internally in the Grid)
3. Have a mouseDownListener on the table (easiest) and call table.getSelection().
4. Exception is thrown:

java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: Index out of bounds
 at org.eclipse.swt.SWT.error(SWT.java:3547)
 at org.eclipse.swt.SWT.error(SWT.java:3481)
 at org.eclipse.swt.SWT.error(SWT.java:3452)
 at org.eclipse.nebula.widgets.grid.Grid.getItem(Grid.java:1636)
 at org.eclipse.nebula.widgets.grid.Grid.getSelection(Grid.java:2161)

Suggested fix:

1. getSelection() in Grid.java should make a check to see how many items there are in the table before trying to call getItem(...). If table item list size is zero then the selection is obviously not valid. 
2. It seems removeAll() should clear selection on the table as well
column11: however;\n\nI'm not sure if the intention is to preserve selection despite an empty table
column12: if so
column13:
at least a check to ignore an out of bounds selection should be made prior to calling getItem() so that no exception is thrown.

Workaround:

Create your own clear() method between your code and the table
column14: in that method
column15: call table.deselectAll() prior to calling removeAll()."

b"Build ID: M20090211-1700

Steps To Reproduce:
1.Instantiate A Grid Widget that has at least 2 rows and 2 columns
2. Set the first column to 'setTree(true)'
3. Run on Windows Environment
4. Run on OSX Environment
5. Observe that the OSX version does not have dotted lines.



More information:
I am trying to get my version of Nebula Grid in sync with the cvs header_footer version and found a minor change I had made to BranchRender.java

It seems when Grid was originally written custom line styles were not supported on OSX so a if statement was added to skip styling on SWT.carbon. This is no longer the case and unneeded"
b'In the reply to Remote_Initialize_Debug_Engine gdbpicl is indicating that it \nsupports load occurrence (FCT_LOAD_BREAKPOINT)
column8:
but when a breakpoint of this 
type is sent to gdbpicl it responds with "breakpoint type not supported".
CmdBreakpointEvent.java only seems to support EPDC.ChangeAddrBkpType.
If you are not going to support load breakpoints for the beta then you should 
turn off the FCT bit.  However
column9:
you should add support for this at some point 
(if gdb supports it).

FCT bit has been disabled.
We may need to add support for load breakpoint in the future.'

column7:
b'Created attachment 196234 [details]
Patch for the time step splitting

If a value is negative after performing a time step
column8: a smaller time step is performed. Afterwards an additional step for the remaining time is done. If a value is negative again
column9: the this time step is split again and so on.'

b'This is the same or similar problem as reported in bug # 13748.  I looked at 
this bug report and saw that it was closed with the assumption that the cause 
was due to a pre-5.x IE version of the suspect dll (comctl32.dll).  I am 
running IE 5.5 (5.50.4807.2300 to be exact) and the version of this library I 
have is 5.81.4807.2300.  In comparison with others here using Eclipse 
successfully
column8: some have this same version
column9:
some slightly earlier 
(5.81.4807.1100).

I have been running fine for weeks until I did a refresh and rebuild all of a 
large project.  After that
column10:

column7: b"When using eclipse in a Gnome2/GTK+ v2.2.0 setup (implemented on debian unstable\n(sid))
column8: with the Crux theme
column9: it is impossible to open (java) source files. \nDoing so results in a crash of the IDE.  It is perfectly possible to navigate\nthrough the IDE (open up perspective
column10: checkout projects from CVS
column11: etc.)
column12: but as\nsoon as one double clicks a file in the Java/Resource perpective
column13: instead of\nopening the file
column14:
the IDE crashes.  

Eclipse keeps working perfectly when using other theme engines than Crux. 
Looking at the error message eclipse generates (see lower)
column15:
it looks like it is
problem with the crux theme engine where some precondition is violated. 

Further info:

column7: b'The I20040324 build was packaged with the swt-xxxx-3043.so libraries instead \nof swt-xxxx-3044.so. The map file has been updated and the next integration \nbuild will catch the correct version.'

b'From Konrad:

It looks like the browser installed with RHEL 3.0 does not meet requirements 
of SWT.  I have RHEL3.0U1 with all RHN updates
column8: and they upgraded Mozilla to \n1.4.2
column9: which I am afraid is not GTK version.  If you would like to see the \nbrowser embedded
column10: a different mozilla (GTK2 build) needs to be installed'

column7:
b'Running a test case that uses the ProgressListener.completed event causes a 
NPE when trying to get the widget field.

Widget field is not set and should contain the browser the event originates 
from. The other browser events appear fine.'
b'we need to replace spaces with %20 as expected by Safari API'

b'Press F5 inside the Intro page in Eclipse . 
IE refreshes the URL (about:blank) - causing a blank page to be displayed.

setText is used to render html in memory.

We should probably block default IE accelerators when URL is about:blank so 
that the content of setText is not cleared when the user presses F5.'

b'The SWT Browser (using the sample plugin) seems to crash with
EXCEPTION_ACCESS_VIOLATION using every Applet demo listed here:
http://java.sun.com/products/plugin/1.5.0/demos/plugin/applets.html
Namely
column8: the Clock example
column9: Simple Spreadsheet
column10: Simple Bar Chart
column11: and \nGraphLayout.'

column7: b'Eclipse 3.0 RC3
column8:
mozilla-1.4-3.0.18

Confirm dialog doesn't work in the embedded Mozilla browser widget (work in the 
external Mozilla browser). Here's a testcase:

<html>
  <body>
    This is a test.
  </body>
</html>
<script language="javascript">
  if (confirm("This is a confirm dialog"))
    alert('You clicked OK');
  else
    alert('You clicked Cancel');
</script>

In the external Mozilla browser
column9: the confirm dialog and the alert dialog show \nup correctly. However
column10: in the embedded Mozilla browser
column11:
the confirm dialog 
doesn't show up at all.

Studio v6's Web services tooling
column12: more specifically
column13: the Web Services Explorer \nis depended on this fix for the Eclipse 3.0 timeframe.'

column7:
b"v3101

1. Run the attached example jar on the Pocket PC.  
2. Select ComboExample from the list and press Run.  You'll get an 
UnsatisfiedLinkError for org/eclipse/swt/internal/win32/OS.GetComboBoxInfo."

b'eclipse-sdk-3.0.1rc2-linux-gtk-amd64.zip contains bad sources for GTK native 
part. In arcive plugins/org.eclipse.platform.source.linux.gtk.amd64_3.0.1/src/
org.eclipse.swt.gtk64_3.0.1/ws/gtk/swt-pisrc.zip sources cannot be compiled 
because they contain Windows elements like HMODULE and FARPROC. 

This source was produced by org.eclipse.swt.tools which contained bug 68855.'

b'To reproduce on windows
rename the org.eclipse.osgi_3.1.0 to be _org.eclipse.osgi_3.1.0
start eclipse --> you get an error indicating that something is in the log.
Do "Alt-tab" and notice that the icon is incorrect.'

column7: b'Code complete includes fields and methods that are not code legal in the current\ncontext. For example
column8: code completion shows private methods defined in Object.\nThis not only clutters the code complete dialog with tons of useless data
column9:
it
also generates compiler errors if a user unwittingly selects a private/protected
field/method out of context.

The results of code complete should be filtered by protection and context.'

column7:
b"build 20011106

-Open org.eclipse.swt.internal.win32.OS.java in the java editor.
-Place the cursor somewhere at the beginning of a line near the top of the file
-Press and hold the delete key to delete the line
->You should see a reasonably smooth delete operation

-Go a few pages down in the file (within the top 1/8 of the file is enough)
-Press and hold the delete key to delete one of the public static fields
->The delete operation is so slow that the screen doesn't update anymore.
Something is taking away too many CPU cycles."

b"The 'typecomment' template has the following default value:

/**
 * @version  1.0
 * @author
 */

The 'filecomment' template has the following default value:

/*
 * (c) Copyright 2001 MyCorporation.
 * All Rights Reserved.
 */

Both of these templates are on by default. This leads to
the Java editor adding inappropriate comments to every source
file generated.

Recommended behavior:
(1) The default 'typecomment' template should be completely empty.
(2) The default 'filecomment' template should be completely empty.
(3) Both templates should be on by default. With empty templates
column8:
bogus class javadoc and file header comments will be not generated.

This means that a user that actually changes these templates to
have suitable values will automatically reap the benefits."

b'Created attachment 231135 [details]
Slide with clarifying details

See attached slide for info.

Currently
column8: not any of the properties of applied profiles are displayed.\nThis means that the user have no idea which version it has
column9: only the name of it
column10:
so there is no way to confirm that a model applies the "correct" version of a profile.

The user also have no idea where the applied profile is located
column11: that is
column12: \nif it\'s a local profile in the workspace/project or a profile registered in the runtime.'

column7: b'Assume a model defined in another tool which uses datatypes
column8: in a different model
column9: also defined in the same other tool (not UML Primatives
column10:
but instead UML Datatypes).

Now I now import the model defining the datatypes into Papyrus and then import the model using the datatypes into Papyrus. The latter will not use the datatypes of the former. Instead I will have a broken model.

To fix the model I must manually replace all the references from the .x -> .uml

The same is the case for UML dependencies.'

column7: b'Running the Refactor->Switch Libraries action causes certain models to lose stereotypes. We will provide more details in a further comment. Also it should be noted these side-effects are visible when the Apply button is pressed. Selecting cancel on the popup window does *not* undo the side-effects caused by the apply. Ctrl+Z once the popup has been dismissed is the only way to undo the damage.'
b'Test execution shows severe performance regressions
column8: initially attributed to the StereotypeElementListener.  It does unnecessary work and throws lots of exceptions
column9: which likely also contribute to performance slow-down (all that work of filling in stack traces
column10: unwinding stacks
column11:
logging exceptions).

column7: b'+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #251715 +++\n\nProjects must have stated and demonstrated their intent to join Galileo by the M4+0 date.  Projects do so by adding themselves to this bug and each of the P1 bugs used to define "Must-Do" requirements for train participation.'
b'+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #252789 +++\n\nAt least one person from each project must subscribe to cross-project bug inbox
column8: i.e. edit Bugzilla prefs to watch "cross-project.inbox@eclipse.org". Build team members (or their designated alternates) from each project will provide communication channels: phone
column9: mail
column10: IM
column11: IRC and will be available during the milestone integration periods.'

column7: b'+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #252790 +++\n\nProjects must have an project plan in XML format.'
b'+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #252791 +++\n\nProject representatives must attend the planning meetings and conference calls - you have to be involved to be involved.'
b'+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #252796 +++\n\nProjects must use 4-part version numbers.'

b"+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #252800 +++\n\nProjects must use jar'ed plug-ins (with unpack=false) unless authorized by the planning council for technical reasons. Nested jars should be avoided if possible since it creates problems for projects that has dependencies to such plug-ins. The OSGi runtime is fine with it but the compiler is not able to handle classpaths that contain nested jars. In case only one nested jar exists
column8: it is often better to expand the contents of that jar into the root folder (i.e. unnest the jar). If a plug-in contains large files that are frequently used (opened and closed)
column9: a jar'ed plug-in might degrade performance significantly since the file must be decompressed each time it is opened."

column7: b'+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #252806 +++\n\nThis means that users can load any subset of the Galileo projects into Eclipse and each of the loaded projects will pass all the same tests as if it had been loaded independently. If such a problem is identified
column8: the affected projects must fix the problem.'

column7: b'+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #252809 +++\n\nMust use  ICU4J.'
b'There are currently 500+ deprecation warnings in runtime
column8: examples
column9: and test\nplug-ins.  We need to work on removing these dependencies.'

column7:
b'A user may want to add their own custom items to the popup menu when a 
connector handle is dragged from source to target (or vice versa).  The 
GraphicalNodeEditPolicy is not easily extended to do this.  Non-IElementTypes 
should be supported more easily in this popup.  To handle this better
column8: I think \nI should change how CreateUnspecifiedTypeConnectionRequest is used.'

column7:
b"To reproduce:
1. Copy a shape.
2. Paste the shape.
RESULT:  The new shape appears right on top of the old shape.  It's not obvious 
that the paste worked.  The new shape should be offset a bit.  It used to work 
like this."

b'Actions to group / ungroup selections.

Grouped objects create a virtual contaiment so that multiple objects can 
behave as one for movement / style modification.  They can also be modified 
individually with-in the group.

- Custom layout is necessary to supported multiple levels of containment'
b'- Create a diagram assistant tutorial for how to create action-bar and \nconnection handles for a specific domain.'

b'- This is necessary for plug-ins that wish to define a default drawer that \nclients may wish to utilize of not.  i.e. Geoshapes \n- Ability to open the geoshapes palette drawer by default is dependent on this.'

b'GateEditPart
1. In the header you mention this should inherit from GatedShapeEditPart 
eventually.  Is this still true?  The class method signatures seem to support 
this.  What would be the ramfications of making this change.

2. The method "createMainFigure" is never called from anywhere.  Yet the 
getMainFigure is called  using the "getElementPane"  method to return if the 
top level figure is a GatedPaneFigure.  Are these 2 method necessary at all?'

b'Investigation from diagram plug-ins perspective:
- Unicode 3.2
- Collation & Searching
- Locales (270+)
- International Calendars
- Customizable text boundary detection

How much of this will be inherited from SWT / GEF / GMF Common?  Investigation 
will determine what diagram actions are needed.  As a minimum
column8: it may require \na sweep.'

column7:
b'1. References to "Connector" should be "Connection" to be consistent with GEF
2. ActionBarEditPolicy --> PopupBarEditPolicy to avoid confusion with Eclipse
ActionBar terminology
3. Check for spelling mistakes - "Nesteable..." should be "Nestable"
4. Gate infrastructure should be "Border" and "Bordered"
5. ListCompartmentItem.. should simply be "ListItem" to avoid confusion with the
container "ListCompartment..."'

b'To reproduce:
- Create a LED on a GMF logic diagram.
- Use connector handle or palette tool to create a note attachment from the LED 
to an unspecified target.
- Select Note.

RESULT:  Everything is created ok
column8: but the note attachment is highlighted.  I \nthink the new note created should be highlighted so that you can immediately \nenter text.  I think this would be the natural flow.'

column7: b'See bugzilla 109445 for details:\nhttps://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=109445'
b'Work to adopt EMF transaction API in diagram plug-ins.\n\nSee bugzilla 113708 for details.'
b'- GEF allows for palette customization from the UI.\n- Need to integrate this capability and persist it in the workspace.'
b'- It is needed to be referenced in client xml for the palette provider \nextension. i.e. Logic example needs this.'
b'The ActionIds class in org.eclipse.gmf.runtime.diagram.ui.internal.requests \nshould be part of the public API because these IDs are required by clients in \ntheir XML contributions.'
b"If a client is implementing an interface in our public API
column8: it is not possible to add a method to that interface without breaking the client code.  We should look through our interfaces and indicate in the javadoc that they are not meant to be implemented.\n\nFor example
column9: the EditPolicy interface in GEF says the following: * IMPORTANT: This interface is not intended to be implemented by clients. * Clients should inherit from {@link org.eclipse.gef.editpolicies.AbstractEditPolicy}. * New methods may be added in the future. Examples in our code: IDecoratorProvider -- we should create an AbstractDecoratorProvider and clients should subclass this instead. I'm not sure if there are more cases in our code. Maybe we should do a search."

b'When deleting a node via keyboard
column8: a createDeleteSemanticCommand object is generated. If the deleteRequest is a GroupRequestViaKeyboard
column9: it contains a "showInformationDialog" field. This field should be passed to the DestroyElementRequest
column10: but it\'s hardcoded to always be false. \n\nSee Line 148 in ComponentEditPolicy'

column7:
b'Running the CHKPII and SEGCHK tools on the GMF code reveals some errors and warnings in GMF.  I ran the tools on all GMF plugins.

Error:  914      Separator between string ID and text should be '****'.  May be invalid text continuation.  Line: ****
Files:  A couple diagram example plugin's messages.properties and plugin.properties 
Fix:  Contained ':' instead of '='.  Easy to fix.

Error: 910   Invalid comment delimiter (/*) used in PropertyResourceBundle.
Files:  A couple diagram example plugin's plugin.properties and plugin.properties 
Fix:  Remove the invalid comments.  Easy to fix.

Warning:  920      (W) Unknown single quote handling for this file.  Special NLS_MESSAGEFORMAT comment should be added.
Files:  In all(?) messages.properties and plugin.properties files.
Fix:   Need to include a NLS_MESSAGEFORMAT comment in each messages.properties file to indicate how single quotes should be handled.  Depends on if we are using MessageFormat class or not so we should sweep to make sure we are no longer using this class (we can use the NLS class now).  I'll have to read into this more to figure out what NLS_MESSAGEFORMAT comment we should include
column8:
but it should be a relatively easy fix.

Warning:  131   (W) SegChk SE0006  Isolated coordinating conjunction "and" found.  
Files: a few messages.properties files
Fix:  There are some "and"'s alone in the messages.properties file which means they are being concatenated incorrectly somewhere.  These need to be changed.'

column7: b'CreateUnspecifiedTypeRequest override setLocation() and call setLocation() for all the wrapped requests
column8: but do not override setSize() method. As a result
column9: al the wrapped requests (passed to the command to process in future) do not get an information about actual size of object to be created.\n\nAs a result
column10: all the diagram elements will be created with default sizes
column11: instead of selected with the creation tool.'

column7: b'It is a simple fix
column8: which has a really big impact. BasicNodeViewFactory has getEditingDomain() method
column9: which should be propagated up the hierarchy. When ConnectionViewFactory creates a view
column10: it should call this method to obtain editing doman rather then TransactionUtil.getEditingDomain(edge). The BasicNodeViewFactory way of obtaining it goes a step futher - it looks for the editing domain of the semantic element (is there is one) first. In some cases we do want to have views which are not attached to a resource
column11: but thier semantic element is.'

column7:
b'- Change your display settings to be high contrast mode and a color scheme where the background is black (e.g. white on black).
- Open a GMF diagram.
- Try to use the palette to create a shape.
RESULT: The cursor does not show up when you are hovering over the diagram even though everything does work fine.

This is an accessibility issue.'

column7: b"I noticed that right after 10:00AM this morning (here in Berlin)
column8: the download.eclipse.org became unresponsive.  I have a feeling that's related to the automatic update checking in the IDE that by default is set to kick in every Tuesday at 10:00AM.  Surely it's a bad thing to have all running Eclipse installations in any given time zone kick in at the same time and hammer download.eclipse.org with requests for p2 metadata?"

column7:
b"Build 20020813

For some reasons F3 and F4 stopped working in several views.
Also
column8: [Delete] key doesn't work anymore in Search view without having changed\nanything there. I heard about an SWT change in that area? Since we are in\nnon-breaking API mode for 2.1 I guess this changes needs to reverted."

column7: b"I20021015\n\nWith the latest Integration Build
column8: the DEL key doesn't work anymore in all the \nTreeViewers (at least in those I tries: Navigator
column9: Package Explorer and Outline)"

column7:
b'GTK and Motif have significant performance problems using the hidden menu in 
its current form. I looked at a profile and found that at least 700ms is spent 
in AcceleratorMenu.setAccelerators on these platforms (every time we 
recalculate the menu - which can be as often as switching editors). I am hoping 
that this has to do with the fact that the hidden menu is being disposed of and 
recreated with new menu items each time setAccelerators is called. Can someone 
look at this
column8: and perhaps reuse MenuItem instances if that proves to be the \nproblem?'

column7: b'In using the menu command Import File -> Import ...

column7:
b'20021218

It is not currently possible to get the IME anywhere in Eclipse in Linux GTK.

STEPS
1) Change Locale to Simplified Chinese before logging in
2) Go to any application except Eclipse.
3) Hit Ctrl-Space. IME comes up.
4) Hit Ctrl-Space again. IME closes.
5) Start Eclipse
6) Go to a text file. Hit Ctrl-Space. Nothing happens.'
b'Keybindings are stealing native KeyEvents to SWT Controls.\n\nIf I have the GEF Logic example (and only its required plugins)
column8: it will \nreceive the F2 KeyEvent from a Canvas.  If I then add the JDT to the set of \nplugins
column9: the F2 keysroke is registered as "show tooltip" for the Java Editor.  \nThe mere presence of this keybinding definition is enough to steal the F2 key \nfrom the Logic example\'s Canvas.  The same is true for Control+"/"
column10:
and lots of 
other combinations.

Additional Keybinding are blocking native windows keystrokes for SWT controls 
required for accessiblility purposes.

Control+UP/DOWN: mapped to scroll editor up/down
column11: but *SHOULD* allow me to \nchange the focus in a SWT.MULTI List
column12: Table
column13: or Tree.\n\nContrl+SPACE: mapped to content assist
column14: but should allow me to toggle the \nselected state of the current Tree/Table/ListItem in an SWT.MULTI List
column15: Table
column16: \nor Tree.'

column7:
b'OS: Win 2k
Eclipse Build: Stable Build (M5)
JRE Version: JRE 1.4 IBM build and IBM JRE 1.3.1

Abstract: Cannot launch Eclipse with Turkish locale

Re-produce steps:
1. Change Regional Options to Turkish
2. Launch Eclipse

Expected Result: Eclipse should start up.

Execution Result:
1. Splash screen is displayed and freezes.
2. No log file is created.

Comments:
1. This problem occurs with both IBM JRE1.3.1 and JRE1.4.0.
2. This problem does not occur for stable build M4.'

b'I20030722

CTRL + 1 does not work anymore with the latest build:
- The preference page has the key assigned to Quickfix
- The menu (Edit->Quick fix) does not contain the (CTRL + 1) in the name'
b"In a modified version of the KeySequenceText (one that uses the MacOS X approved\nmenu font)
column8:
backspacing until the last key stroke is deleted resets the font. 
Future key presses have unprintable characters (because MacOS X special menu
characters aren't supported in the font it is reset to).


STEPS TO REPRODUCE:
1.) Open the KeysPreferencePage and change the focus to the KeySequenceText widget.
2.) Type in an arbitrary key sequence (e.g.
column9: Shift+E
column10: Command+X)\n3.) Press backspace until all the key strokes are removed.\n4.) Type in another key sequence with a special character (e.g.
column11:
Command+Delete).


ACTUAL RESULTS:
The special character is not in the font it is supposed to be -- possibly
unprintable.

EXPECTED RESULTS:
The same font should appear as in step 2."

column7: b'There should be a API to limit the maximum number of KeyStrokes that the\nKeySequenceText will allow in its KeySequence.'
b'The characters displayed in the KeySequenceText should be the real characters
column8: \nrather than their shifted values -- when using shift.  In other words
column9:
the
natural key should be the key that would have been typed if shift had not been
down at the time of the key stroke.


STEPS TO REPRODUCE:
1.) Open KeysPreferenceDialog and focus on the KeySequenceText widget.
2.) Type "Ctrl+Shift+6".

ACTUAL RESULTS:
"Ctrl+Shift+^" is inserted.

EXPECTED RESULTS:
"Ctrl+Shift+6" is inserted.'

b'latest from head as of Sept. 27 2003
on top of build I20030719

- launch target
- set key bindings into emacs mode
- open a text file
- click in a word
- Esc D
- has no effect (should delete next word)

- go to key bindings page
- Text Editing / Delete Next Word shows Esc D as one of the bindings
- type Esc D in the key sequence field
- you get: Esc Null'

b"build I20031021

- open Keys pref page
- select command File / Close
- no bindings appear
- Ctrl+F4 and other bindings appear to work OK even though they are not shown
- I had previously defined Ctrl+W for File/Close and it is not working
column8:
however 
I had also bound Ctrl+Shift+W for File/Close All and it is working.  This may 
be due to the scope problem for Ctrl+W - I normally have to define it in the 
text scope as well as the global scope in order to work around a (known) bug.  
Close All doesn't have this problem."

b'When the right hand edge of Eclipse is near the edge of the monitor the editor 
drop down menu gets cut off.  Maximizing Eclipse does not change this.  I am 
running on a machine with a dual monitor setup.  Note the menu is not spanning 
monitors as in defect #51240 but actually cut off.

I have "Show multilpe Editor tabs" turned on.  I can also get this to happen 
with that preference turned off the but I have to size Eclipse down from the 
left such that the single editor tab does not fit on screen - then the editor 
drop down clips on the right even though there is plenty of room on the left.'

column7: b'With bug 432940 fixed
column8: we need to provide a preference page to be able to add / remove / enable / disable Tern plugins.\n\nI envision the page would be very similar to the current plugins page.'

column7: b'Opening many of our CSS files results in a sea of blue that makes it impossible to see what is actually wrong in the file. For 14.0 we should look at turning down the severity of these issues (to ignore). Longer term we can improve messages and fixes (see Bug 513250).\n\nThe highest priority is adjoining classes
column8: which is only an issue in IE6 and we use them frequently in our theme CSS.'

column7: b'If the user opens a model dialog (like a wizard or a property page) while \nfollowing the instructions of a CheatSheet
column8: access to the CheatSheet is \nblocked. This makes CheatSheets less useful
column9:
because often the part the user 
needs help with is in some modal dialogs.

One solution could be
column10: to make cheat sheets to run in an external executable \n(that would be a nice example of a RCP application)
column11: so the cheat sheet is \naccessible in the modal context....'

column7: b"Now that we have dynamic content
column8: searching needs to be updated. We cannot index filtered content because we may miss hits later on when the filter properties change
column9: and because the environment where the docs were indexed can be different from the machine it is running on. For those interested and for future reference
column10:
here is the approach taken:

For indexing:

- Index the documents unfiltered
column11: but with all content extensions
column12: topic replacements
column13: and includes resolved. This immediately rules out false negatives (hits that we should get but we don't) because we have all the content there and potentially more. However we can get false positives (e.g. if I have a linux only section in my doc that I'm viewing on windows).\n- While indexing
column14: keep track of all the filters a document is sensitive to. For single value filters like os
column15: ws
column16: it simply stores the name. For multi-value filters like plugin where there can be many
column17:
we store the full name and value (to denote: this doc is sensitive to whether plugin X is present or not)

For searching:

- Do an initial search pass on the master index. For each hit
column18: check what filters the doc is sensitive to. If it has any filters
column19: it is potentially a false hit and we flag it as such. Hits that don't have filters are definite hits and we're done with these.\n- If we found potential false hits
column20: we perform a second search pass for the potential false hits only
column21: but on the cache index. This index has documents indexed with all content resolved and filters turned ON
column22: unlike the master. Initially it will be empty - it is built up as needed. For each hit we check what the filterable property values were at the time we indexed this doc. If they match
column23: the cache is up to date and it's a real hit. If it doesn't match or one of the potential false hit docs wasn't indexed
column24: it is flagged as needing reindexing. So the whole purpose of the second pass is to determine whether the cache is up to date
column25: and if not which parts are outdated.\n- For each doc needing to be reindexed
column28: for the filters this document is sensitive to
column29: store the actual values of the filter properties. e.g. if the document is sensitive to os and we're running in linux
column30: store os=linux. This will be used in the future to see whether the doc is out of sync or not.\n- Perform a third and final pass on the updated cache again. This time anything we find is a definite hit and we add it to the definite hits bucket.\n- If we had to do a second and third pass
column31:
sort the final results by score.


The end user implications are that searching dynamic content may be slow on the initial searches where docs with dynamic content contain the search word(s). This is because it has to reindex these docs and resolve all extensions and filter the DOM. However subsequent searches should be fast
column32: as it will use the cache. If you change your activity enablement and you have docs that filter by activity
column33: docs may need to be reindexed here as well.\n\nThis doesn't affect infocenter because it doesn't filter
column34: so the second and third passes are omitted in this case and there is no need for a cache index."

column7: b"Back in 3.1
column8:
UA introduced pre-built indices so that the initial user experience becomes much more pleasant when doing that first search.

We were all oh so very proud that the first search went down from 40 seconds to 1 second.

I don't know what happened since.  We seem to have had a regression.

A search on a brand new installation (e.g. on the I20061024-1200 build) took 10 seconds or so."

column7: b"Currently if you store some doc plugins on a remote help server
column8: then get a client to point to it
column9: the client will see all documentation available even if the client doesn't have that component.\n\nThere needs to be a way to associate doc plugins with UI so that the client can only show what is relevant."

column7: b'I have been trying the OpenType dialog with a small to midsize project (1300 \ncpp files).   (Using CDT Head - from this morning
column8:
and Eclipse 3.0M9)

Here is some background on the project:

 1. The project has  been previously indexed (Image grew from 48M to 
116M
column9: took about 9 minutes to index)
column10:
and 
 2.  Code assist and search work reasonably well (although sometimes 
quite slow).  
 3.  Closing eclipse and restarting it causes no re-indexing at all. 
(image is now 48M)
 4.  I have the "cache types in background" flag off

 5.  The first time I use the OpenType dialog (after restarting 
eclipse)
column11: it takes a minute or so to "Updating Type Cache"
column12:
6.  Each subsequent invocation is instant.

This looks great!  

Now here is the problem:
 The memory requirements on step 5 have jumped by 160M
column13:
I think that 
this will not scale well....


There was no parsing being done (I have a breakpoint on Parser.translationUnit)

Has anybody else measured something similar?'

Project setup: it's a JPA project (facets: Java 7
column12: JPA 2.1)
column13:
with the following configuration:
- platform = Generic 2.1
- library configuration disabled
- connection: a defined connection to a MySQL database
- discover annotated classes automatically
- no source defined for canonical metamodel

The persistence.xml is almost empty:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<persistence version="2.1" xmlns="http://xmlns.jcp.org/xml/ns/persistence" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://xmlns.jcp.org/xml/ns/persistence http://xmlns.jcp.org/xml/ns/persistence/persistence_2_1.xsd">
 <persistence-unit name="myPU">
 </persistence-unit>
</persistence>

The JPA libraries are added to the project classpath by using Gradle
column14:
which adds the following JAR to the project classpath through a dedicated container:
- org.eclipse.persistence.core-2.5.0.jar
- org.eclipse.persistence.asm-2.5.0.jar
- org.eclipse.persistence.antlr-2.5.0.jar
- org.eclipse.persistence.jpa-2.5.0.jar
- org.eclipse.persistence.jpa.jpql-2.5.0.jar
- javax.persistence-2.1.0.jar

The result is the same if I add the User Libraries by downloading EclipseLink 2.5.2 libraries using the JPA configuration wizard in Eclipse instead of providing the JARs by myself with Gradle.

The project is defined in the workspace but physically resides in a folder outside the workspace folder (it's linked in the workspace
column15: using the "Import Existing Project into Workspace"). Could it be this the problem?'

b'Build ID: WTP 3.0 05/19 RC1

Steps To Reproduce:
The eclipselink JPA platform is defined as default="true"
column8: which prevents adopter products from making their own JPA platform the default.\n\nEither the eclipselink JPA platform should not be the default
column9: or some mechanism like product preference customization should be used to allow adopters to guarantee which platform will be used by default.\n\nMore information:'

b'The UI should support the following new JDT Core feature:
Search for field read and field write references. Two new constants have been 
added on IJavaSearchConstants to be used when creating a field reference search 
pattern:
    - READ_REFERENCES: the search results contain *only* read access to a field.
    - WRITE_REFERENCES: the search results contain *only* write access to a 
field.

If REFERENCES is used
column8: then search results contain both read and write accesss \nto a field.'

project

you should be able to get a

p.s. Note that Person_Pickler_Vj.class is IMPORTANT. This class file 
does not have corresponding source file.'

b'Build 20020910
Linux-GTK

If I try to turn off the "Hide binary plug-in projects" filter on the 
packages view
column8:
Eclipse hangs with my CPU pegged at 100%.

Here's what I did (this is reproducible with my workspace):
1. Launch Eclipse pointing to an existing workspace that has the filter set 
on the packages view to hide binary projects.
2. Check out a project from CVS (I used org.eclipse.ant.ui) which already 
exists in the workspace in binary.
3. The packages view does not update to show the project which is no longer 
binary (there's already a bug report for this problem elsewhere).
4. Bring up the "Filter..." dialog for the packages view.
5. Uncheck the "Hide binary plug-in projects" option.
6. My CPU usage goes to 100%
column9: my mouse is grabbed (this is an SWT-GTK bug)
column10: \nand the Eclipse UI stops responding.'

column7: b"Hello
column8:
I would like to propose a new kind of view we can find in other IDE like sharp
develop for instance. It is the scout view (in #develop idiom) and consists in
proposing in a palette vieww by category code snipets that we can drag and drop
into the current editor. For some kind of works
column9: it is better than code assist\nbecause we can't recall in mind every key shortcuts
column10:
and it is a good help to
have  that presented visually.
http://www.icsharpcode.net/OpenSource/SD/Tour/094/ToolScout.aspx
best regards
Xavier"

Here's the detailed test case:

1. Extract official 0.132 to a new location
2. Replace the Debug and JDT plug-ins (in eclipse/plug-ins)
 Note: You have to create them first from the currently released 2.0 dev stream.
  Or: you use 0.132 as is but then you have start Eclipse on Eclipse on Eclipse to see the bug
3. Start Eclipse
4. Add Eclipse code to the new and empty workspace (self-hosting setup)
5. Add the program arguments to UIMain
6. Launch UIMain (i.e. Eclipse on Eclipse)
7. Close Eclipse (started on Eclipse)
8. Re-launch UIMain via running man menu: UIMain [Java Application]

I assume this has to do with the introduction of the launch memento."

DW (6/7/01 2:16:38 PM)

column10: but hard to implement. The java model in the IDE does\n not know about the launched program
column11:
or what JRE it is running with. The source lookup is
 performed in the IDE with the JRE that is present.

DW (6/7/01 6:35:30 PM)

 in the IDE.

b'Stepping out of an Object.wait() call causes the debugger to hang.

To reproduce:

1. Import sources from wait.zip
2. Debug Main
3. Pause Producer Thread
column8:
step over until you are at the line that reads
fConsumer.consume(); (Producer.java line 17)
4. Pause Consumer Thread
5. Do a step out on the Consumer Thread
6. Do a step over on the Producer Thread

Now the stack looks like:
Main at localhost:13023
 System Thread [Finalizer] (Running)
 System Thread [Reference Handler] (Running)
 System Thread [Signal dispatcher] (Running)
 Thread [Consumer] (Stepping)
 Thread [Producer] (Suspended)
 Thread [Thread-0] (Running)

But there are no children of the Producer Thread
column9: and the Consumer thread should\nhave returned from its step.'

column7:
b'Build 20011127
Windows NT 4.0
SDK running on IBM JRE 3.0

JDIValue.evaluateToString(IJavaThread) uses wait(long) for timeout in a wrong 
way. The spec for this method says that the VM can throw an 
InterruptedException at any time (even if the amount of time has not expired.)

Running Eclipse on IBM JRE 3.0
column8: I can see that indeed the VM throws this \nexception early (i.e. before the 3000ms of timeout I have set). As a result
column9:
most of the details of the variable show up as <timeout> or <error>.

I would suggest to use the same pattern as in PacketReceiveManager.getCommand
(int  command
column10: long timeToWait) to solve this problem.'

column10: but I was being lazy and figured I could \nclick on "Step over" 7 times quickly instead). After 3 or 4 clicks

column7: b'After a hotswap
column8:
we should only pop frames that are obsolete. We should be able 
to improve our dopping behavior by improving out "obsolete" detection. It might 
be possible to compare method byte codes before/after a hotswap (at least on 
J9).

Otherwise
column9: we should be able to use fine grained deltas (based on resource \nhistory) to determine which frames to drop.'

column7:
b'build 20011206

The debugger seems to be leaking huge amounts of memory.
When I start a program (SwtStyledTextUseCase) in debug mode the Eclipse memory 
load increases by about 8MB. When I quit the debug session the memory load 
decreases by less than 1MB. When I do the same in run mode the memory load goes 
back to about where it was before.
I can repeat this about 12 times until I reach the heap size limit and Eclipse 
dies a slow death (see bug 7006). This means I have to restart Eclipse after 
about 12 debug sessions.'
b'This is not an easy bug to reproduce. I have only seen it during remote \ndebugging
column8: but on some occasions (not while debugging) when I connect to the \nremote VM and set the breakpoints
column9: the program stops and in the debugger I can \nsee the line number
column10:
but when I click on the stack the corresponding class is 
does not come up in the editor and the current line is not highlighted. 
Restarting eclipse along with the application being debugged solves the 
problem. Since restarting is necessary
column11: this is a very annoying bug. I will try \nto add detail if no one reproduces it.\n-Leon'

b'We have an application that launches a command-line process using \nRuntime.exec()
column8:
then uses Process.getInputStream() to read what is output on the 
console.  It has a loop waiting for the stream to be ready() before actually 
trying to read any input.  When running this application from the command line 
or from Kawa (our hopefully soon-to-be-previous Java development environment)
column9: \nthis works fine.  However
column10: when running (or debugging) under Eclipse
column11:
the call 
to ready() never succeeds.

This is done during the startup of our application
column12:
so we are completely unable 
to run or debug using Eclipse because of this problem.

Here is a small
column13: self-contained example program that illustrates the problem.  \nIf you run or debug this in Eclipse
column14: it will hang on the while(!in.ready()) \nloop.  If you run from the command line
column15: using the class file compiled by \nEclipse

column7: b'This is BUG 11144 which has been fixed in Eclipse 2.0.  Given many\nIBM products now use Eclipse 1.0
column8:
is it possible to get an
efix to apply to the existing 1.0 products that fixes the problem
in the scrapbook?

We don't have to have the "run in package" option
column9:
just the ability
to at least pickup the configured build path for the current app
context for the scrapbook page and (the corresponding snippet class).

If we can get an efix for 1.0 then I can avoid writing a tip that
says don't use the Java scrapbook in all these IBM products...

Thanks for your help...

Jim Mason'

column7:
b'I launch eclipse as follows:

D:\eclipse\eclipse.exe -data d:\hbnet\workspace

When I create a new "Launch Configuration" the "Working directory" on the 
arguments page of the Launch Configurations dialog box is D:\eclipse which is 
grayed out when the checkbox "Use Default working directory" is checked.  This 
default location is completely useless.  I would expect that the default 
directory would be the root of the project for which the configuration is being 
created.

Since you have to associate a launch configuration with a specific project
column8:
what I expect is that the default working directory to 
be "d:\hbnet\workspace\myproject" (given the above -data directory example). 

If it worked as I described
column9: then launch configurations could easily be shared \nwith other people that have their workspaces in different locations.  As it \nstands now
column10: I need to uncheck the "use default working directory" box in the \nlaunch configuration and specifiy "d:\\hbnet\\workspace\\myproject" manually.  \nWhich works fine for me
column11: however when I check this into CVS and someone else \ngets the launch configuration
column12: the directory "d:\\hbnet\\workspace\\myproject" \ndoes not exist on their computer because they have their workspace in a \ndifferent directory
column13:
so they have to hand modify it.  

If it worked the way I expected (using the project root at the default 
directory for a launch configuration)
column14:
no modfications would be needed and 
shared launch configurations would work great.

Setup: Using M5 on Windows'

column7: b'Source lookup appears broken for non-workspace JRE.'
b'20011018 Drop\n\nI attepmted to use a JDK that had a sourc jar file
column8: but it doesn\'t work When the\nlocate source dialog pops up in the debugger
column9:
it appears that the JDK_SRC
classpath variable points to "src" and not to "<jdkInstallDir>\src.jar".

A workaround it to define a new FOO_SRC variable
column10: and assign it to point to the\nsrc.jar.  However

column12: because you need to redo\nit every time you start the workbench.'

column7: b'This test always fails for me when I run it. There appears to be a subtle \ntiming issue
column8: as if I debug
column9: and step through it
column10: the test passes. For some \nreason
column11: the variables of the top stack frame are not being refreshed properly
column12: \nand the test cannot find the local variable named "product".'

column7: b'The debug and run menus give a list of the latest commands at the top.  However
column8: \nthis list appears to be shared
column9: and selecting an entry that was previously a run \nfrom the debug menu causes a run
column10: not a debug.  This is confusing.  Also
column11:
there 
is no information in the menu indicating whether the command was a debug or run.  

I can see at least three ways to resolve this:

Each menu should have it's own latest menu.
The menu contains info as to whether the command is run or debug.
The command takes the context of the menu it is in.

More info on the third option:  Let's say I run a java application.  I then want 
to debug it.  It shows up on the debug "latest" list
column12: but rather than submitting \na run again
column13: it submits a debug for the same program.'

b'Doing an open type in while the cursor is in DelegatingMethodsAccessImpl
results in an empty Error dialog.
The walkback entry is generated when running junit.samples.SimpleTest on JDK 1.4

 at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke
(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:28)'
b'Writing a lot of data to the console crashes Eclipse.\nTo replicate
b'1. In a selfhosting environment
column8:
put a breakpoint on the first line of
JDIStackFrame#popFrame() (the line should read "if (supportsDropToFrame()) {").
2. Launch a target Eclipse and debug a program in the target Eclipse with a JDK
1.4 compliant VM.
3. Cause a hot code replace (the target suspends at the breakpoint in JDIThread).
4. In the host
column9: perform a StepOver.\n5. Note that instead of stepping to the next line
column10: the debugger is now in the\ncalling method as if a StepReturn had been performed.'

UI plug-in which uses the deprecated code will no longer compile. See previous 
revision of FormattingContextProperties and ContextBasedFormattingStrategy for 
tips to resolve the problems.'

column7: b'The title of the Error Parsers page for managed build should reflect that the \nBinary Parsers tab is there as well. My recommendation is "Error and Binary \nParsers"
column8: or just "Parsers" if that is too long.'

column7: b'I\'d like to see full text search functionality inside task comments across all tasks/ all tasks of a repository. The standard "Find" box seems to filter based on task title only.\nUse case: I remember some resource mentioned in one of my many tasks/bugs
column8: but can\'t remember which one.'

column7:
b'To reproduce:

# copy the attached stack trace to the clipboard
# open any Bugzilla task in the Mylyn task editor (markup enabled)
# paste into the new comment part
# observe that Eclipse hangs and never comes back

The stack trace of the hung thread is also attached.  
Might be related to bug 264345.'
b'I did some very quick and inconclusive benchmarking
column8: and it looks like there is a 2-3x slow down in task editor open compared to having WikiText diabled.  I tried Confluence syntax with JIRA and Textile with Bugzilla
column9: and both appeared to exhibit this.  We need to do additional performance profiling in order to determine where the bottleneck really is.   This is very high priority because task editor open time is a key point of friction that we have been working hard to minimize.'

column7: b'If a user clicks on each of the tabs it seems like the content is not cached.  For performance reason the client should cache the content of the tabs.'

b'Bug 278102 adds a quick outline for the task editor which conflicts with the WikiText quick outline if a WikiText enabled text field is focused. In all other SDK editors the quick outline is page or editor global rather than specific to controls and the task editor should follow that convention. I suggest to map the WikiText quick outline to Ctrl+Shift+O or to disable it when the task editor context is active.'
b'When installing software through the MPC
column8: the MPC consults all known p2 repositories.  To be specific
column9: when you select a component from the market place
column10: the MPC first computes the "URL" (update site) for this component
column11: but then the install operation loads this URL plus ALL OTHER p2 repositories to determine the dependencies.  \n\nFor example
column12: I have 10 repositories listed in my Available Software sites
column13:
and when I install a component through the market place all 10 repositories are first fetched and loaded.

This approach has a number of problems:

1. Performance.  The fact all repositories are first loaded means that all repositories must be reachable (or we timeout trying).  For example
column14: at EclipseCon where we sometimes have a dedicated server
column15: if we hosted a marketplace on that dedicated server it would not matter because clients would still attempt to reach the outside world for each install.  This also means that as clients start using both p2 and the MPC to install things
column16: they will begin to face serious performance hits.\n\n2. Authenticity of what I\'m installing.  If I list a URL for my component at the market place
column17: then I assume that this URL will be the one consulted when the component is installed. However
column18: if the same component is listed in more than one p2 repository
column19: then it\'s anybodies guess which repository will actually provide the component.'

b'When filters are added in the following manner:
   <extension
           id="myfilterId"
           name="myFilter"
           point="org.eclipse.ui.ide.resourceFilters">
  <filter selected="true"  pattern="*.txt"></filter>  
 </extension>
Mylyn does not preserve the filter in focused mode.   This is because there is no backing class. This is a problem in the resource navigator view and in new file creation dialog.'

b'I\xe2\x80\x99m working on my diploma project for the University of Applied Sciences
in Biel (Switzerland) and I\xe2\x80\x99ve been working with the EMF/JET to generate
editors for models based on xsd. As expected it worked great for the
generation of eclipse editor plugins
column8: but when it came to generation of\ncode for completely different purposes I had to notice
column9:
that the
generation was hardcoded and not really adaptable. It only is possible to
change the templates for the artifacts to be generated.

Wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t it be possible to let the whole GenModel follow the
Visitor/Visitable pattern? What actually is generated would be implemented
in Visitors visiting the GenModel. E.g for the generation of Eclipse
editor plugins based on a GenModel there would be a specific
EclipseEditorVisitor which would be packaged as an extension point to the
GenModel plugin. In order to generate completely different artifacts for
the GenModel it\xe2\x80\x99d be enough to implement a GenModelVisitor and package it
as a plugin providing an extension point to the GenModel plugin.'

b'I get this error: ---------------------------------------------------------- Unable to complete action for feature "Graphical Modeling Framework (Callisto Edition)" due to errors. The File "/tmp/1895651917/eclipse/.update/1151741076112/1151741076216/eclipse38969.tmp" is not a valid JAR file. [error in opening zip file] The File "/tmp/1895651917/eclipse/.update/1151741076112/1151741076216/eclipse38969.tmp" is not a valid JAR file. [error in opening zip file] ---------------------------------------------------------- The file containts this: ---------------------------------------------------------- Menu for /eclipse/callisto/releases/plugins/org.eclipse.gmf.map.edit_1.0. 0.v20060627-1200.jar

Menu for /eclipse/callisto/releases/plugins/org.eclipse.gmf.map.edit_1.0.0.v 20060627-1200.jar

[an internal server error occured] ---------------------------------------------------------- It seems that the mirror (I was using SWITCH in Switzerland) couldn't deliver the file for some reason. When I download it manually
column8: it works.\n\nI tried to start the update again but when I don\'t restart Eclipse
column9: it uses the cached files (which is usually clever but not in this case).\n\nNext
column10: I deleted the faulty file and restarted the update (which means I have to remember what I wanted to install in the first place ...).\n\nEclipse didn\'t like that at all: Now
column11: I got an IOException.\n\nSo I did a touch of the file. Now
column12:
Eclipse pretended to download it again but the file just contains the error above once more.

So I downloaded the file and overwrote the faulty one. That's a bit hard because:

1. I have to figure out the download path somehow (the path in the error message is just relative to the update site path)
1. Eclipse somehow notices that the file was changed and tries to download it again. For some reason that always fails with the same error despite the fact that I can download it with wget (I tried 5 times).

But I found a workaround:

First
column13: I move the faulty file away. Then
column14: I copied the download to the name of the faulty file and lastly
column15: I reset the date with touch -r
column16: to Eclipse couldn\'t see the difference.\n\nNow
column17:
the update worked.

But it would be better if there was a more simple way :-) Update should really check whether the file it downloads is actually what it expects.

Maybe you should add file size and MD5 checksum to site.xml.

I'm wondering though
column18: why the download in Eclipse always fails while it always works with wget :-/'

b'A kind reviewer noticed the following errors in some of the Orbit bundles for which I am responsible ... so
column8:
plan to fix these before ganymede release. 
Most are just copy/paste sloppiness on my part. 




o org.mozilla.javascript 1.6.6: version in about.html says 1.6.2
o org.uddi4j (v2.0.5): plugin.properties file doesn't have standard Eclipse license/copyright notice.


o org.apache.xml.serializer: 
*the about.html will have to be updated to reflect that the content in this plugin comes from Xalan and is used as part 
of Xerces-J 2.9 (serializer.jar).
*the Xalan-J NOTICE file is missing.  The content in this plugin originates from the Apache Xalan-J project.  

*(minor) there's no need for the LICENSE-SAX* (1file) and LICENSE.DOM* (2 files) files to be present because that content is in the javax.xml plugin - likewise
column9:
readme.dom and readme.sax files can be removed 
*(minor) there is no need for the LICENSE-resolver file to be present as that content is in the org.apache.xml.resolver plugin.

o javax.xml: 
*(minor) no need for license.resolver file to be present as that content is in the org.apache.xml.resolver plugin.
I think the only content that should be mentioned in the about is what is included with the plugin

column7: b'+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #252798 +++\n\nAll plug-ins must correctly list their required JVM versions in the manifest.mf. See the wiki page about selecting the correct JVM.'

b'+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #252799 +++\n\nProjects must use signed plugins using the Eclipse certificate. Exceptions must be authorized by the planning council for technical reasons.'

b"+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #252800 +++\n\nProjects must use jar'ed plug-ins (with unpack=false) unless authorized by the planning council for technical reasons. Nested jars should be avoided if possible since it creates problems for projects that has dependencies to such plug-ins. The OSGi runtime is fine with it but the compiler is not able to handle classpaths that contain nested jars. In case only one nested jar exists
column8: it is often better to expand the contents of that jar into the root folder (i.e. unnest the jar). If a plug-in contains large files that are frequently used (opened and closed)
column9: a jar'ed plug-in might degrade performance significantly since the file must be decompressed each time it is opened."

column8:
we have historically always used the following URL for our update sites:

column9: this needs to change
column10: for a few reasons. For one
column11: (if we have to change it anyway) the term "updates" is now inaccurate or at least old-fashioned ... it is more of a "repository". \n\nAlso
column12: because we now want repositories to persist forever
column13: it is too "high level". For each major release
column14: we should have one specific to that release. Also
column15: using the "version number" is pretty old fashioned too
column16:
and I see no reason not to use the yearly release name. such as 

http://download.eclipse.org/webtools/repository/helios


While we can (and should?) still provide 
http://download.eclipse.org/webtools/repoository 
as a viable URL
column17: it is anticipated that
column19: it would perform slower and slower
column20: so it would be best to normally point people to a more specific one
column22: while not normally advertised to most users
column24: we will have separate ("hierarchical") repositories for each maintenance or off-cycle release. Currently
column25: I\'d prefer date-time-stamp directories for these (rather than
column29: because then "off cycle" release fit in more naturally
column30:
so these very specific URLs would look like 

http://download.eclipse.org/webtools/repository/helios/201006260900/

So
column31: the suggestion is that for feature update URLs

the value would be

We'd probably want to do this by M6

column7: b'One awkward aspect of our procedure has been how to get "affirmative" joining of release train
column8: and coordinating that with contribution files. For past few years
column9: this has been done by copying previous year\'s files
column10: but disabling contributions and requiring projects to consciously "join" be enabling their contribution. \n\nBut this is disruptive
column11: since often for first milestone or two
column12: people are merely contributing their "previous release"
column13: but if it is disabled
column14: then others "above" them in the chain are broken until the "lower" projects re-enable their contribution. \n\nWith the change in procedure of "announcing" participation
column15: as announced on cross-project list
column16:
and described in 
http://waynebeaton.wordpress.com/2013/09/09/eclipse-luna-whos-in/

and with the Foundations databases updated based on that announcement to seed the "participating" list at sites like
https://projects.eclipse.org/releases/luna

it will be possible to leave everyone "enabled"
column17: at the beginning of a new year. \n\nBut
column18: there will be a point when a project has not "announced" ... either because they\'d forgotten
column19: or because they really are not going to participate any longer ...  but they will still have a file in org.eclipse.simrel.build. And
column20: with historical examples
column21: sometimes they will continue to "build" without anyone ever noticing. \n\nSo
column22: we still need a "disable" and eventual "remove" procedure. And that\'s what this bug is about. \n\nI propose that if a project (that was previously participating) has not announced by the end of M2
column23: that they be disabled right after M2. That should "shake out" anyone who\'s merely forgotten
column24: so if by the end of M3 (right after M3 comes out) the contribution will be removed. Since "brand new" projects have until M4 to join
column25: this means by M4 we should have a completely accurate "picture" who\'s in and who\'s not. \n\nTo cross-reference
column26:
this bug is related to bug 298259. 

See also bug 416861 for an alternative view and comment there if desired. 
(But
column28:
we want to meet all the objectives outlined in 
http://waynebeaton.wordpress.com/2013/09/09/eclipse-luna-whos-in/ )

I wanted to open this bug to give projects a chance to comment before this goes into effect next year. If there's no alternatives that come up
column30: I\'ll document this on wiki and count this as resolved.'

column7: b'The purpose of this bug is to track "migration" of certain cronjobs to a \nHudson HIPP Instance "owned" by Platform releng. By making is "specific" to releng team
column8: it allows some work to be done for Platform and Equinox (see bug 486401) without opening up security issues too much. \n\nThis may be a "temporary" solution until all our entire builds can "run on Hudson". But since that is a year or more away
column9:
this allows incremental progress to be made. 

The "first wave" will be to move what some committers have as "cronjobs" to this Hudson instance. 

The "second wave" would be to use this Hudson instance instead of "e4Build" to do more work. This minimizes the number of committers (or build IDs) needed with "shell access" to eclipse.org. 

The reason I am motivated to do this now
column10: is so that it would be easier for other committers to "back up" our core release engineering team (i.e. me :) in the\nevent they were not available ... or
column11: others
column12: such as John Arthorne had a cronjob related to Equinox Download page
column13: and since he is becoming inactive at Eclipse
column14: having that cronjob run here allow others to pick up that work
column15: if changes needed
column16: or similar.'

column7: b'I am opening this bug to discuss if we *need* a (public) 4.5.2a build due to a regression introduced via bug 378811. \n\nThe issue is in some ways "small" because it only affects those that want to use "e4" but without the SWT widgets. But
column8: on the other hand
column9: "huge" since it blocks those adopters completely and was a long promised design principle of e4. \n\nAt first
column10: I thought we did need a new build and repository because the issue originally reported in Tycho bug 488725 had to do with "the repository" -- and those that specify "noenv" (which I had never heard of before :). \n\nBut
column11: upon second reading
column12: it seems that it was only related to using a composite repository for a build -- that a simple repository still worked (even though it had the wrong feature and dependencies). And
column13: using a composite repository for "builds" is not a good practice anyway. Not to mention
column14: if the composite is "broken" due to conflicting "filters" then there is no way to fix it by adding to it -- there will still be conflicting filters in the composite. \n\nSo
column15: if we do not do a 4.5.2a build
column16: then how to deliver the fix for 378811? Will a "feature patch do"? Or do we do a "quite" 4.5.2a
column17: since as far as I know this only affects one adopter: e(fx)clipse. Does anyone know of others that use "noenv"?'

column7: b'This is purely my work item. But recently I made a job on Hudson to "promote" a Sim. Rel repo from "staging" to "releases". And something went wrong since it did not include the mirror.url nor "stats" line. (Thanks to Ed Merks for pointing this out BEFORE it was released!) \n\nSo
column8: the "Hudson promote" script needs work. Bot to "work correctly" and to "fail" if something goes wrong.'

column7: b'Thought best have a reminder bug open that once we start new builds (in July?) that we need to change the "streamless" URLs -- one of those "once a year" tasks.'
b'Ideally
column8:
all that is needed is document in 
https://wiki.eclipse.org/Platform-releng/Updating_Branding

But
column9: instead of reading that I will list what I recall off the top of my head -- then can see if something is omitted from Doc
column10: or omitted from my head. :) \n\nMost "branding" changes for 4.6.1 are all version related. Almost anywhere in "aggregator" or "platform" or "platform.releng" where it says "4.6 or 4.6.0 needs to be changed to 4.6.1
column11: such as for "product" versions and the .eclipseproduct file. \n\nIn addition
column12:
where we have "train name" as "Neon" most (if not all) occurrences should be changed to "Neon.1". 

The splash screen should be changed to say "Neon.1" instead of "Neon". 

= = = = =

The build scripts are relatively easy to change. There is a place in the "bootstrap" file (such as mb4m_hudson.sh that gives the branch as R4_5_maintenance that will have to change to R4_6_maintenance. 

Once branched
column13: a new repositories* file needs to be created that is named \nrepositories_R4_6_maintenance.txt and as content
column14:
each repository changed to R4_6_maintenance. 

A copy of "index.template_master.php should also be made that is named 
index.template_R4_6_maintenance.php. The contents stay the same
column15: though.'

eclipse.platform.releng and eclipse.platform nearly all occurrences of "4.6" should change to "4.7". 

Occurrences of "Neon" should change to "Oxygen". 

And

column7: b'Another "todo" item is to decide and implement where to "permanently" put the output of the p2repo.analyzers build. Currently
column8:
in one place (Platform releng) we use simply use the "lastSuccessful" build *product* from the build. 

  wget --no-proxy --no-cache -O "${TMP_DIR}/${tar_name}" https://hudson.eclipse.org/cbi/job/cbi.p2repo.analyzers.build/lastSuccessfulBuild/artifact/output/products/${tar_name} 2>&1

In another place (SimRel aggregation builds)
column9:
I use the repository from a specific build and install it "into" a base platform using p2 director: 

https://hudson.eclipse.org/cbi/job/cbi.p2repo.analyzers.build/9/artifact/output/p2repo/

I would prefer to maintain only a "permanent" update site
column10: but will have to determine if it easy enough to document "how to get the product" from that repository
column11: if that is what users would prefer.'
