b'Both the marquee tool (not the drag tracker version) and the connection \ncreation (again
column8: not the drag tracker version) should be unloadWhenFinished\n(false) by default.'

column7: b'if platform = "gtk"
column8: we should release the button model immediately on \ndragStarted
column9: unless viewerExited comes before that even (GTK only).'

column7: b'+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #251715 +++\n\nProjects must have stated and demonstrated their intent to join Galileo by the M4+0 date.  Projects do so by adding themselves to this bug and each of the P1 bugs used to define "Must-Do" requirements for train participation.'
b'+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #252789 +++\n\nAt least one person from each project must subscribe to cross-project bug inbox
column8: i.e. edit Bugzilla prefs to watch "cross-project.inbox@eclipse.org". Build team members (or their designated alternates) from each project will provide communication channels: phone
column9: mail
column10: IM
column11: IRC and will be available during the milestone integration periods.'

column7: b'+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #252790 +++\n\nProjects must have an project plan in XML format.'
b'+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #252791 +++\n\nProject representatives must attend the planning meetings and conference calls - you have to be involved to be involved.'
b'+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #252792 +++\n\nProjects must have a written ramp down policy by M6+0
column8: linked in the table above pending inclusion of ramp down element in the XML project plan. (One of the issues identified with this guideline is that its not so much the ramp down policy of how many votes are needed for each bug fix that we need to be consistent on
column9: but rather the meaning of each of the milestones and release candidates. See Platform 3.4 Endgame plan as a guideline. See also Galileo Final Daze.)'

column7: b'+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #252793 +++\n\nProjects must have their IP approved (a normal Eclipse requirement) and will follow the Eclipse Legal deadlines to do so. See also bug 220977.'
b'+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #252794 +++\n\nProjects should leverage only published APIs of dependencies. As a Release Review requirement
column8: deviations should be listed as part of a migration plan
column9: with bugs listed where APIs need to be provided by dependent projects.'

column7: b'+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #252795 +++\n\nProjects must use Eclipse message bundles unless there are technical reasons not to. (see Message Bundle Conversion Tool and [1])'
b'+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #252796 +++\n\nProjects must use 4-part version numbers.'
b"+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #252797 +++\n\nAll plug-ins (bundles) must use the true bundle form. That is
column8: provide a manifest.mf file
column9: and not rely on the plugin.xml file being 'translated' into a manifest.mf file at initial startup. See bug 130598. With that
column10: empty plugin.xml files in the presence of a manifest.mf file should not be included in a bundle."

column7: b'+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #252798 +++\n\nAll plug-ins must correctly list their required JVM versions in the manifest.mf. See the wiki page about selecting the correct JVM.'

b'+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #252799 +++\n\nProjects must use signed plugins using the Eclipse certificate. Exceptions must be authorized by the planning council for technical reasons.'

b"+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #252800 +++\n\nProjects must use jar'ed plug-ins (with unpack=false) unless authorized by the planning council for technical reasons. Nested jars should be avoided if possible since it creates problems for projects that has dependencies to such plug-ins. The OSGi runtime is fine with it but the compiler is not able to handle classpaths that contain nested jars. In case only one nested jar exists
column8: it is often better to expand the contents of that jar into the root folder (i.e. unnest the jar). If a plug-in contains large files that are frequently used (opened and closed)
column9: a jar'ed plug-in might degrade performance significantly since the file must be decompressed each time it is opened."

column7: b'+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #252801 +++\n\nProjects must have build process maturity: scripted
column8: repeatable
column9: and executable by others.'

column7: b"+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #252803 +++\n\nAny new third-party plug-ins that are common between projects must be consumed via Orbit; the final Galileo release will not have duplicate third-party libraries (note that this only applies to identical versions of the libraries; thus if project A requires foo.jar 1.6 and project B uses foo.jar 1.7
column8: that's ok)."

column7: b'+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #252804 +++\n\nProjects must optimize their own update site using pack200 to reduce bandwidth utilization and provide a better update experience for users. With the introduction of p2
column8: project update sites must generate metadata (artifact and content repository info).'

column7: b'+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #252805 +++\n\nMust have new & noteworthy for each milestone. Must be something readable and usable not just a static list of all the bugs
column8: e.g. platform. Corollary: individual new & noteworthy should be linked in to the collective New & Noteworthy.'

column7: b'+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #252806 +++\n\nThis means that users can load any subset of the Galileo projects into Eclipse and each of the loaded projects will pass all the same tests as if it had been loaded independently. If such a problem is identified
column8: the affected projects must fix the problem.'

column7: b'+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #252807 +++\n\nEach project will provide basic capability/activity definitions to allow for their UI contributions to be hidden. These must be provided in a separate plugin/feature to facilitate inclusion/exclusion by consumers in product development.'
b'+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #252808 +++\n\nThe project participates in Babel
column8: meaning it is registered and available for string translation
column9: etc.'

column7: b'+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #252809 +++\n\nMust use  ICU4J.'

b'+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #252813 +++\n\nEach major project (the top-level projects except for the Tools and Technology projects where it is the sub-projects) should have an About dialog icon and contribute to the welcome page.'

b'Build 20020328

The configurations in the launch history don't seem to get updated when you 
change the JRE used by the configuration.  This is best explained by showing the 
steps I followed.  I don't know if this is intended behaviour
column8:
but I found it 
quite confusing!

1) Setup a self hosting environment
2) Create a launch config for Runtime Workbench using IBM JRE as the VM
3) Perform a launch (debug mode) using this configuration
column9: then shutdown\n4) Use Debug dropdown button
column10: pick "Debug Configurations..."\n5) On this page
column11: change the JRE of runtime workbench to J9.\n6) Hit apply button
column12:
then close this dialog.
7) Now use the debug history to try launching the runtime workbench

It fails to launch (UnsatisfiedLinkError: setClassPathImpl).  I spent quite some 
time at this point trying to figure out why it wouldn't launch with J9.  
Finally
column13:
I stumbled on the answer:

8) Reopen the debug configurations dialog
9) Select the runtime workbench
column14: and hit the "Debug" button\n\nNow it launches.  After launching
column15: the debug launch history now shows two \nidentical entries for runtime workbench.  One uses J9
column16: and the other uses IBM \nJRE
column17: but they are impossible to distinguish.'

column8: check all \nother senders. The dialog should only register saved launch configs."

3. Launch Eclipse.

Execution Result:
1. Error message is displayed.
2. Eclipse cannot be opened.

Comments:
1. This problem occurs on eclipse M4 with Sun JRE1.4.0. when launched on the 
Hindic locale.
2. The problem does not occur on Websphere Studio Workbench packaged with the 
IBM JRE1.3.1

English locale

column7:
b'Who is affected: System integrators/product developers expecting to configure 
overlapping sets of plugins with different version numbers into one Eclipse 
install.

Description: Eclipse allows multiple versions of the same plugin to co-exist. 
Since OSGi resolves package imports/exports to one version it does not support 
multiple plugin versions. There are two proposals for adding multiversion 
support to the OSGi framework. Both are feasible but differ in how version 
differences are propogated. 

Analysis: This usecase is real and the lack of support is temporary. The 
Equinox team is busily working on this issue and hope to resolve it shortly.'

column7: b'The Eclipse adaptor is storing various framework data (state
column8: bundle metadata
column9:
etc) in binary form on the file system.  The data needs to be versioned so that 
if/when the format of the data changes then the eclipse adaptor can detect the 
version of the data on disk and migrate it to the new format.'

column7:
b'Other clients (besides the framework) will need to have access to a state
implementation that they can use (such as the model API in regular Eclipse that
allows PDE Build to create a plug-in registry and compute build paths).

Also
column8: clients should be able to create bundle descriptions given\nplug-in/fragment manifests or bundle manifests (in the same way we provide\nPlatform.parsePlugins in regular Eclipse).'

column7:
b'The state cache has a version identifier. We should discard the state and build
it again from scratch if the cache version does not match the version we expect.

See also bug 46449.'

column7:
b'There are various cases where the runtime fails to start.  Typically the user 
gets some generic "unable to find application" style message with no 
explanation as to why or what to do about it.  

There are several steps to solving this problem
1) improve initial messages to more accurately reflect what has gone wrong.  
For example
column8: if we know/suspect that it is a resolution problem
column9:
print a list 
of the unresolved plugins.

2) Provide tools to introspect the configuration and understand why things are 
unresolved/resolved.  Nothing too grand is required here but some basic reports 
(what is resolved what is not) and the ability to choose a bundle and in the 
console find out more about it (what is it bound to
column10: if unresolved
column11: what is \nmissing
column12:
...)

It is extremely important that we give good (accurate and informative) feedback 
in the case of errors.  Currently we can't even figure out what is happening 
and we understand how the systme works!'

column7:
b"If a Platform.restart() is invoked during the WorkbenchAdvisor.initialize()
phase a crash will occur with Eclipse 3.0 M8.

The root cause is because during the
org.eclipse.ui.internal.Workbench.shutdown() method the following line is invoked:

    activityHelper.shutDown();

but the activityHelper method is not initialized (in Workbench.init(Display)
method) until _after_ the workbench advisor is initialized.

Two possible fixes:

Simplest is to change the above line of code to be:

    if(activityHelper!=null) activityHelper.shutDown();

Alternatively one could consider moving the initialization of the activityHelper
to _before_ the advisor initialization.  I don't know all the ramifications of
that.  Even if moved
column8: one should still do a null check during shutdown.  One\ncan't be certain just when a shutdown is going to occur so it is not safe to\nassume that all instance variables have been initialized."

column7: b'A user on eclipse.tools.jdt reports extreme slowness when compiling his project if APT is enabled
column8: even if the processor is implemented as a NoOpProcessor.  An excerpt of the forum thread follows
column9: followed by some console thread dumps taken during a typical slowdown.\n\nNote that although APT is enabled
column10: the call stack is not inside a processor; rather
column11: we\'re inside AST generation.\n\nI\'m assigning this to JDT Core rather than APT
column12:
because I suspect someone from the compiler team will need to help troubleshoot.  The problem may be incorrect use of JDT APIs by APT; reassign to APT as appropriate.



Forum excerpts (edited together from several posts)

[...] Until recently
column13: where my IDE started becoming much less responsive. I didn\'t know what it was due to
column14: until it became unbearable: now
column15: saving certain files requires about 10 seconds. Turns out that disabling the annotation processing makes it recover its snappiness instantly.\n\nI did some basic profiling in my annotation processor
column16: and found that my code was not the bottleneck. It executes
column17: for a single file
column18: in about a tenth of a second. Actually
column19: even if I return AnnotationProcessors.NO_OP from my AnnotationProcessorFactory
column20: saving is this incredibly slow.\n\nHere\'s typical stack traces of the two threads that are most active when compiling takes so long (see end of message -- and sorry for the long post!). Looks like newReconcileEnv and newBuildEnv
column22: take a lot of time. I fail to see what would be the problem
column23: though...\n\nI tried doing the annotation processing only on build and not on reconcile. I also tried returning an empty list for the supported annotation in the factory -- no luck
column24: still takes ages to compile.\n\nMy annotation processor doesn\'t generate source files. The slow files are the Java files which use my custom annotations
column25: or (apparently) other Java files which cause those annotated classes to be recompiled. This happens when I save them manually from the Java Editor
column26: or whenever it is rebuilding the workspace.\n\nI created a new workspace and imported all projects
column27:
copying them into the new workspace with the Eclipse import wizard. Compilation was slow immediately.

There is nothing in the error log. Nothing on the terminal either.
> Is it possible that the slowdown correlates with an increasing use of 
> annotations in your project?  I think that when annotation processing is 
> enabled
column28:
the compiler (before it even gets to processing) has to scan for 
> annotations; I wonder whether that scan is bogging down?  A couple of thread 
> dumps may help to answer that question.
It looks like it could be an explanation... But I'm unsure about the 
interpretation of the thread dumps
column29:
though.

b"Until PR 1G2QFBA: SWT:WINNT - Font metrics wrong for some italics fonts\nis fixed
column8:
we can't support italics properly.

NOTES:

LK (1/18/01 3:30:40 PM)
 Low priority until someone asks for this.

LK (1/30/01 11:58:30 AM)
 Supporting this is now further complicated by the fact that we are using bit bltting when typing.
 Italic fonts won't hold up to the bltting. We did this to improve performance on Linux.

LK (2/7/01 12:04:18 PM)
 Opened 1G8SBZX: SWT:WIN - StyledText - Italic fonts and bltting overhangs on our end.
 This will deal with the bltting problem when the font for the entire widget is italic.  Still not going
 to do individual italic styles until someone asks.

LK (2/7/01 12:11:18 PM)
 We don't support italic fonts for the entire widget.  Cheese will occur during text changes (due to our
 bltting) and when changing from italic bold to italic regular (and vice versa).  In these instances
column9:
more of the changed text area has to be drawn in order to deal with overhangs.  See PR
 1G8SBZX: SWT:WIN - StyledText - Italic fonts and bltting overhangs.  Moving to Inactive.
 
LK (2/8/01 12:06:13 PM)
 Also see PR 1G8SBXB: SWT:WIN - StyledText - Italic font and bold styles not working together.
 Mentions that for a lot of italic fonts the baseline seems to different from the bold version."

column7: b"In the GEF plugin (for fear of being labeled a framework) we do not cache Fonts.\n\nSo
column8: we have a new version of our wrappered GC (called Graphics) that scales all \nof the calls to it.  So
column10: y
column12:
and disposed at the end of the operation.

The problem with this is that it takes at around 2-30 seconds to create a Font 
on Motif.  On windows
column13: creating the same Font is around 1000 times faster. It \nwould be understable if there was a 1-time hit for using a certain font
column14: but \nthis isn't the case.  As a result
column15: doing anything in GEF on Motif with zoom \nenabled feels extremely slugish
column16: and is unusable.  We cannot release our zoom \nfunctionality in this state."

b'Bug: GB18030: Open file containing some special GB18030 characters cause 
Eclipse crach in GTK.


OS: RedHat 8.0
Language: Simplified Chinese
        
Eclipse Build:           200302061700 Stable Build (M5)
JRE version: 
        JRE 1.3.1 IBM build cxia32131-20021102 (JIT enabled: jitc)

Summary: I import two files containing different GB18030 chars and then open 
them in editor. One of the files opens correctly while the other causes 
Eclipse crash.


<<Steps to recreate problem>>
1. Launch Eclipse for GTK
2. Click menu File->Import...
column8:
then select File system. 
3. Import two file: Meng.txt and Wei.txt.
4. Double click Meng.txt to open it in editor.
5. Double click Wei.txt to open it in editor.
6. Press page down in the editor to check the rest part of Wei.txt.

<<Error>>
    After step 4
column9: the file was opened correctly (as is shown in Meng_Good.jpg).\n    But after step 5
column10: Eclipse crashed (as is shown in Wei_Crash_Window.jpg). \nAt the same time

the Terminal window that running Eclipse generated some 
error message (as is shown in ConsoleOutput.txt).

    In Eclipse with JRE 1.3.1
column12:
sometimes we can import and open the Wei.txt 
correctly. But Eclipse can not startup next time.

<<Expected Result>>
       Files containing any GB18030 chars should be imported and opened 
correctly.

Comments
    1)This bug occurs in both GTK 2.0.6 and GTK 2.2.0.
    2)This function works with Eclipse Motif and Windows build.'

column7: b'Take the propertysheet as an example. If you select a project and try to click\non the +/- next to the "Info" category entry
column8:
it won't expand/collapse. 

In this particular case if you click just on the upper-left corner of the box
around the +/- you may be able to get it to work. But if you click anywhere else
it won't work.

In this particular case
column9:
TableTreeItem.getImageBounds() was returning a box that
was lower than where you were clicking such that the event location only
overlapped the image bounds at the upperleft corner.

However
column10: there is also a problem in that getImageBounds() doesn\'t return a\nrectangle with any dimensions many times. With the standard properties for\nthings like project
column11: there are no expandable properties other than the "info"\ncategory. But in our editor (Java Visual Editor) we have many such properties.\nAnd during testing
column12: even though there were some entries that showed a +/-
column13: the\ngetImageBounds() returned a zero-sized rectangle for all of them. Though it\nwasn\'t consistent. It would return zero-sized most of the time
column14:
but not all of
the time.

This makes the property sheet unusable for expanded properties and categories.'

b'Cursor level is broken in the following cases:\n\n1. doBackspace()
column8:
doDelete().
Expected behavior: cursor level is set to the level of the deleted character.
Actual behavior: cursor level is set to the level of the preceding character.

2. doLineStart()
column9:
doLineEnd().
Expected: cursor level is derived from the paragraph level.
Actual: cursor level is derived from the level of the first/last character.

Suggested solution: cache cursor level in the above methods.'

column7:
b'M8

The characters entered using the IME are not rendering correctly in a default 
text editor. This worked in 2.1.3. Please note that this is an issue using the 
default courier font 

STEPS
1) Invoke the IME using Ctrl+Space
2) Switch to Chinese input (by selecting the Chinese button rather than theA 
on the control
3) Enter sey
4) Hit space - you will get a list of possible characters
5) Select the one that matches the one you typed (7th entry on my machine)
6) It will be rendered as a box (this was rendered correctly in 2.1.3)
7) Switch to a GB18030 font 
8) Enter sey
9) Select the one that matches the character - a different character is drawn 
(once again correct for the same font in 2.1.3)

In 2.1.3 characters are correct for both courier and the Chinese 18030 font.'

- emf-sdo-xsd-SDK-I200809161800
- emf-transaction-SDK-I200809221455
- GEF-ALL-I200809091900
- gmf-sdk-2.1.2

I've regenerated the model code
column9: and also the diagram code. Nothing worked. Has nothing to do with XML encoding. Even starting a new diagram
column10: things are shown messed up.\n\nThe problem is located in org.eclipse.draw2d.text.TextFlow.paintText(Graphics g
column11: String draw
column12: int x
column13: int y
column14: int bidiLevel)\n\nprotected void paintText(Graphics g
column15: String draw
column16: int x
column17: int y
column19: x
column23: I realized that the value of the text was never scrambled
column24: but rather just drawn incorrectly. This argument was always set to "-1". I hacked it to be set always to something different to "-1"
column25: and it worked!\n\nI suspected from it while trying different eclipse installations
column26: GMF crashed with problems related with com.ibm.icu
column27: where the "Bidi" concept is defined.\n\nDo you have a clue why I\'m receiving "-1" in the BidiLevel?'

column7: b'+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #252790 +++\n\nProjects must have an project plan in XML format.'
b'+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #252791 +++\n\nProject representatives must attend the planning meetings and conference calls - you have to be involved to be involved.'

b'+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #252793 +++\n\nProjects must have their IP approved (a normal Eclipse requirement) and will follow the Eclipse Legal deadlines to do so. See also bug 220977.'
b'+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #252794 +++\n\nProjects should leverage only published APIs of dependencies. As a Release Review requirement
column8: deviations should be listed as part of a migration plan
column9: with bugs listed where APIs need to be provided by dependent projects.'

column7: b'+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #252795 +++\n\nProjects must use Eclipse message bundles unless there are technical reasons not to. (see Message Bundle Conversion Tool and [1])'
b"+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #252797 +++\n\nAll plug-ins (bundles) must use the true bundle form. That is
column8: provide a manifest.mf file
column9: and not rely on the plugin.xml file being 'translated' into a manifest.mf file at initial startup. See bug 130598. With that
column10: empty plugin.xml files in the presence of a manifest.mf file should not be included in a bundle."

column7: b'+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #252801 +++\n\nProjects must have build process maturity: scripted
column8: repeatable
column9: and executable by others.'

column7: b'+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #252806 +++\n\nThis means that users can load any subset of the Galileo projects into Eclipse and each of the loaded projects will pass all the same tests as if it had been loaded independently. If such a problem is identified
column8: the affected projects must fix the problem.'

column7: b'+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #252807 +++\n\nEach project will provide basic capability/activity definitions to allow for their UI contributions to be hidden. These must be provided in a separate plugin/feature to facilitate inclusion/exclusion by consumers in product development.'
b'+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #252808 +++\n\nThe project participates in Babel
column8: meaning it is registered and available for string translation
column9: etc.'

column7: b'+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #252809 +++\n\nMust use  ICU4J.'

b'+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #252813 +++\n\nEach major project (the top-level projects except for the Tools and Technology projects where it is the sub-projects) should have an About dialog icon and contribute to the welcome page.'
b'The Ecore graphical editor should support Generics. In a first time we should at least use notation defined through Label providers defined at the EMF level
column8: then we should think of a more graphical way to show them (see how this is achieved in UML2 Tools for the Template notation).\nWe also expect that Ed will have plenty of good ideas on this subject
column9: and that he could give us the point of view of the modeling community. :-)'

column7:
b'We need EMF actions in the outline tree :
- new child
- delete from model
- control
- validate
- load resource
- ...'

b'Created attachment 95068 [details]
patch for plug-in org.eclipse.emf.tabbedproperties

A new property section for the plug-in org.eclipse.emf.tabbedproperties might be desirable.

The functionality of this section would be to modify the elements of a feature of type List of any EObject. The appearance of the section would be two Lists (one with the candidates to be part of the list and the other with the members of the list) and four buttons Add
column8: Remove
column9: Up and Down.\n\nI am attaching to this feature request a possible implementation of this section.'

b'Build ID: I20080617-2000

Steps To Reproduce:
1. Select a Class
2.Hit Ctrl+C
3.Select the diagram
4.Hit Ctrl+V

An unknown element is pasted ... The workaround to copy/paste elements is to Ctrl+drag the element to copy.


More information:'
b"org.eclipse.emf.ecore.xmi.impl.XMLMapImpl is not threadsafe.\nIn order to work around the problem
column8: we've had to synchronize our access to \nthat package
column9: but that is not an acceptable workaround because the result is \nour web application is single-threaded through the screen display logic. Any \nworkaround?"

 function paramNumber(n num in)

b"As we expand support for inheritance in the EGL language
column8: and expand support for defining multiple constructors in some logic parts
column9: the ezeInitialize method needs to be invoked outside of the constructor. \n\nFor JavaScript
column10: since we have written our own definition of a Class
column11: which involves the invocation of a function named 'constructor' as part of object instantiation
column12: I believe we will only need to add a call to 'eze$$setInitial();' before we invoke the 'constructor' function in defineClass."

NE (06/11/01 10:01:27 AM)
 See 1GE8K2O: ITPUI:WIN98 - GDI usage stats for opening perspectives

ARCH (7/11/01 11:11:01 AM)
 Fix in 1.0

NE (07/19/01 2:31:16 PM)
 ImageDescriptor.createImage() is spec'ed to always return a new image
column9: \n so it can\'t return null
column10: and can\'t return a shared image (i.e. the missing image).\n And it can\'t be changed to catch the out-of-handles SWTError and create a new missing image
column11:
since it's out of handles.

 Only alternative is to change all cases to use ImageDescriptor.createImage(boolean)
column12:
and handle the null case and SWTError.
 
 SWTError states: SWTErrors should not occur in typical programs
column13:
although "high reliability" applications 
 should still catch them.
 Could change ImageDescriptor.createImage(boolean) to catch the SWTError for the out-of-handles condition
 (SWTError has a code)
column14: and have it return null.  So this would avoid the need for all users to catch it.\n\n Of course
column15: it would be better not to run out of handles in the first place
column16:
but we can't control this in general.
 We can only minimize the number of images we create.


KH (8/1/2001 8:37:17 AM)
 Your proposal makes sense. Hold off making these changes until the SWT team fixes their part of this 
 problem. They are going to be releasing changes that significantly reduce the number of images that need
 to be created. 

NE (8/8/2001 3:19:49 PM)
 Try changing ActionContributionItem to not create extra images on Win98: disabled and hot image.
 Use the hot image as the regular one.'

column7: b'During a "New" wizard
column8: if an SWTError is thrown while building a wizard page
column9: \nthe error is not handled
column10:
and the IDE process terminates abnormally (i.e. no proper
shutdown allowing edit sessions to save).  This will cause data loss and perceived
instability in the IDE.

The problem is likely going to happen with any runtime exception
column11: but I\'ve only\nseen it with SWTError.  In particular
column12:
an SWTError was thrown under Linux when
Combo.setItems(list) was called where list[0] == null.  This doesn't cause an SWTError
in Windows.

To reproduce this
column13: take any New wizard (eg new Java Project). In the \ncreateControl() method that builds the wizard page content as called by \nWizard.createPageControls
column14: manually throw an SWTError (throw new SWTError("oops");).  \nThis is just to simulate an actual SWTError that might be thrown for a variety of \nlegitimate reasons such as low system resources.  With that throw in place
column15: run the \nIDE and attempt to create the new object.  When you click Next from the first\nwizard page
column16: and it attempts to build the page we modified createControl for
column17: \nthe IDE will simply shut down.  I expected that the error would be caught
column18:
and
the current operation (creating a new Java Project for example) would fail and
info written to .log.

Here is the stack trace that was dumped to stdout in my case:

column7:
b'Repeated opening and closing the resource perspctive leaks.

To recreate: 


   Launch fresh eclipse install.
   Close the resource perspctive
   Do a GC and take a snapshot if you are running OptimizeIt.
   Perspective->Open->Resource
   Popup the menu in the shortcut bar and close the perspective
   Do a GC and notice that there are many objects that are still hanging around.


Observations: 

   There are two leaks

        WorkbenchWindow.showShortcutBarPopup(MouseEvent)
        ShowViewMenu

In WorkbenchWindow.showShortcutBarPopup()

   - A perspctive and a page are being held onto on each invocation. 
     Look for declarations of "page" and "persp" as final varabiables

   - Notice that the Menu is not being disposed. 

   - You should be able to dispose of the popup menu. There are SWT defects
     that currently prevent this from happening

        menu.setVisible() returns after the menu has been dismissed on Windows
        but not on Motif

        the selection callback has not been fired after returning from 
        setVisible(). Until this changes you can not immediatly dispose
        the menu. 

        Once SWT issues are resovled the following will work:

                pt = tb.toDisplay(pt);
  menu.setLocation(pt.x
column9:
the contents are static.

The second leak is in ShowViewMenu

    If you follow the steps above and snapshot when the UI is empty a reference
to a page is held onto by the ShowViewMenu. 

    Notice that this class keeps track of the activePage. (BTW this is very 
dangerous as it could get out of date
column10:
would  be better to look it up when you
need it instead of having to manage the reference)

    Anyway
column11: the activePage is only set in pageActivated(). If it is cleared in \npageClosed() the remaining referece to a page is removed and you will now be \nleak free.'

b"In SafeRunnable.handleException(Throwable e)
column8: there is a boolean check that is \ninverted.  Instead of showing Errors
column9: it *NEVER* shows errors.\n\nAs a result
column10: I had my ISelectionListener silently removed from the selection \nservice.  Also
column11: I got into a state where the JDT's F4 action stopped following \nselection
column12: and kept opening a hierarachy on the same class (the last one they \nwere notified about before throwing an exception)."

column7:
b'I had thought that sharing workspaces between products with different plugin 
sets was not supported due to the errors that occur when you do so. 

However I was told that my assupmtion was incorrect. So this bug is to track 
that issue with Views and Perspectives which I assume are the province of the 
UI.

These were using JDK1.3.1 on WSAD based on eclipse 2.0 M5.

I bring up WSAD and open several WSAD projects with an assortment of WSAD 
specfic views and perspectives. Then I shut down WSAD.

Now the following:
1) Launch the base eclipse M5 against the same workspace and I have to wade 
through a *set of error dialogs* about views and perspectives that have gone 
missing. When eclipse finally comes the initial perspective is a Navigator view 
and the other perspectives are still there but seem to be reset to a 
default "Resource" Perspective.

2) I haven't yet tried this (am in the middle of setting it up features for 
WSAD) but it is possible to unconfigure a feature in the update manager so that 
the next time you launch the workbench they don't exist which would give the 
same error as in 1 above I think. I append the results of that as soon as I 
know.


Currently we are on a path of recommending users not to share a workpsace among 
different eclipse based products like WSAD because of these errors.'

b'Build 20020519

1) Start with a new workspace

5) Now launch a runtime workspace with this new plugin
6) Open the "Sample View" created by the plugin

b'Take the F1 build. Open a Java and Resource perspective. 
Activate the java perspective. 
In OptimizeIt do a global GC and mark the allocated objects. 
Activate the Resource Perspective
Activate the Java Perspective

Do a global GC from OptimizeIt

From OptimizeIt there are 10 Accelerators being leaked'
b'Number of editors to reuse should be independent of the number of editor \nworkbooks but seems that if the number is 4 and you have 2 editors workbook
column8:
you may end up with 8 editors.

column9:
the active workbook is 
changed.

I think that making sure the number of opened editors before closing is fixed 
it will make it more predictable.'

b"Build 20020521\n\nOn the Local History preference page
column8:
the max per file setting can only be set 
to 1 MB.  It complains if it's higher or lower.

FileStatesPage.validateMaxFileStateSize() uses:
 workbenchStateSizeMaximum = getWorkspaceDescription
().getMaxFileStateSize() / MEGABYTES;

However
column9: this is the value that the preference page actually controls.\ni.e. it's the current value
column10: not the maximum allowable value.\n\nLikewise for validateMaxFileStates()."

column7: b'All the contents of the perspective (views
column8:
layout info) is lost when the 
following actions are performed in F1:

Maximize a view in any perspective. Switch to another perspective and exit the 
workbench. Open the workbench and switch to the perspective with the maximized 
view. Observe that only the maximized view is actually present and all other 
views are missing from the perspective.

As far as I can remember
column9:
view maximize code replaced the page layout with a 
temporary one that contained only the maximized view. This temporary layout 
must be getting persisted instead of the proper layout when the workbench is 
closed.'

column7: b'When running with Emacs keybindings
column8: Ctrl+space inserts a space instead of \nactivating code assist.'

column7:
b'Build 20020530 + latest UI

Case 1:
- open editors pref page
- change size of recently opened file list to 99
- it complains and disables OK
- restore defaults
- OK is still disabled

Case 2:
- open editors pref page
- select Close editors automatically
- change number to 0
- it complains and disables OK
- restore defaults
- OK is still disabled'

b"0601 candidate 2

Not sure if its SWT or JFace.

Going from Java Browsing Perspective to opening (ie. Window->Open 
Perspective...) the CVS Repo Perspective
column8:
the task view became orphaned.

This to happened in a somewhat fresh workspace. In the screen shot which I will 
attach
column9:
you can see that the task view is left orphaned and floating.  You can 
operate the controls within it but you can move or close it by either the close 
button or popup view menu. Note the task view is not part of the CVS Repo 
perspective.

I noticed this once in 0530?/31?  but couldn't get it to happen again and 
blamed it on low resources at the time
column10: which this shows to be irrelevant."

column7: b'F1. I have seven projects in a workspace
column8: some of which are local to the\nworkspace
column9: some aren\'t. I typically close a project before opening another
column10: so\nas to have only one open at a time. At least twice
column11:
I have seen the following
crash scenario.

Right-click project in Navigator
column12:
Close Project. A dialog appears warning of a
failure to save IStore. Then an Internal Error dialog appears: "An SWT error has
occurred. It is recommended to exit the workbench. Subsequent errors may happen
and may terminate the workbench without warning. See error log for more details."

Truer words were never spoke. An attempt to say No to that dialog just brings it
up again
column13: flickering madly. Unfortunately
column14: Yes gets the same result. The\nworkspace is not exited and needs to be killed. The error log has a number of\nthe following. (I wasn\'t sure how much of the looong stack trace you wanted

so
I cut it off at the last event dispatch.)

column7: b'Build F2
column8:
Win2k

1) Open a Java perspective
2) Window->Reset Perspective
3) Ensure that Tasks and Console views are stacked together
4) Ensure Search view is closed
5) Select the Console view
column9:
then select Outline (or any other view that is not 
stacked with Tasks or Console)
6) Do a File Search on "hello"
7) Close the Search view (it should have stacked itself on top of the Console 
view)
8) Do a File Search again on "hello"

The Search view should be stacked on the Console again
column10: and it should be \nactive.  However
column11: the Console appears to be on top of the stack of views
column12: \nregardless of which one you activate.  In other words
column13: if you select the Task \nview by clicking on its tab
column14: the Task view won\'t appear.  The Console stays on \ntop.  If you select the Console view explicitly
column15: then choose something else
column16:
the behaviour returns to normal.

I'm still trying to isolate the bug but this is the shortest set of steps I 
could find that reproduces the bug successfully.'

column7:
b'build 20020602 (F2)
Tested only on windows

1) Supposed you have Package and Hierarchy together on the same view.
2) Drag the Package view making it be a Fast View
3) Resize the hierarchy view to be wider
4) At this point you got a huge gray area
5) Try switch to another view
column8: look like the old view is around\n\n(no log found)'

column7: b'Build F2
column8:
Win98.

1. Close all Perspectives.
2. Open a Java perspective.
3. Open a CVS Repository Exploring perspective.
4. Go back to Java Perspective via shortcut bar.  Show View --> CVS 
Repositories.
5. Make CVS Repositories a Fast View.  Select it from the short cut bar. Click 
below it on the shortcut bar to close it.
6. Go to the CVS Repository Exploring perspective via shortcut bar.  The task 
view from the Java perspective appears in the CVS repositories window.  

Will attach bitmap.'

column7: b'While testing on Windows 98
column8: I was working in the Resource Perspective and \nmaximized the CVS console view. All views except the navigator disappeared. The \nproblem is easily fixed in many ways (maximize Eclipse
column9: reset perspective).'

column7:
b'F2 build

- do a search that generates some results
- close all perspectives
- open Java perspective
- show view / Search
- it appears with the last search indicated in the titlebar
column8: but also in the \ntab.'

b"If i create my handy dandy editor for XML files and supply it as an Update 
Manager feature. If the user has been working on a workspace already and now
my feature gets added the user has to know exactly what was installed and how 
to find it.  

What is needed is a way for a new feature to announce itself to the user the 
first time it comes up after being installed. At this point if it provides some
editors or perspectives the user should be allowed to set the default 
perpspective/editors for files to the new editor/perspective. 

The plugincustomization.ini is only useful the first time the user starts with 
a fresh workspace. It doesn't handle this case. 

This is important for WebSphere Studio Tools as when the user upgrade from one 
product to another there is no way to make the new function the default or 
even give the user the option to do so"

b'Build 2.0 release Linux/GTK

I got an NPE written to my log while using the switch accelerators on GTK. I
think this was only exposed by bug 21307
column8:
but we should still make the check.

To reproduce:
1) Open several views/editors/perspectives
2) Rapidly hit Ctrl+F6/F7/F8 many times in random order
- This opens several of the switch dialogs
column9:
which do not go away when the Ctrl
key is released.
3) Invoke File->Close All
4) Close the switch dialogs with mouse and keyboard
- The first switch editor dialog will cause the NPE

I could not reproduce the behaviour on Windows or Linux/Motif.'

column7:
b'Installation of an extension must be able to give the user the option of 
customizing the current/default perspective. The behavior should be such that 
the specified perspective becomes the active perspective once the extension is 
installed & eclipse is up again.  The behavior is similar to the first time 
behavior with the default perspective. For example if product 1 was installed 
and product 2 installs as a feature we need the product 2 perspective to become 
the default (if the user so chooses during our install). For upgrades within a 
company
column8: we would likely not even both to give the user the option'

Steps To Reproduce:
1. Open the Open Repository Task dialog (Ctrl-Shift-F12)
2. Enter the key of a Jira issue to load and check to add the issue to a Task List Category
3. To confirm that the handle is incorrect
column8: open the tasklist.xml file in an xml editor - the JiraIssue xml node for this task has attribute Handle of the form "http://<repository>/jira-<key>" when tasks loaded from the repository using other methods (e.g. queries) have a handle of the form "http://<repository>/jira-<id>"\n4. Once this task is closed
column9:
it can not be synchronized/opened because mylar tries to refresh using the invalid handle.

column10: Focused UI
column11: and Task List
column12: and version 0.9.3 of Jira Core Services.\n\nI first noticed this bug because the Task cannot be opened from the Task List once it has been closed

b'It would be nice if the following changes could be made to the automated IP log.  
 
1) Project License - Please add a section on the top of the log indicating which Project License(s) the Project is using:  EPL or EDL.  
 
2)  Committer Section - 

a)  Never Active Committers - If they are never active
column8:
is there a reason why we are not asking them to go to the portal and deactivate?  
 
3)  Third Party Code
Automated tool now lists all EPL CQs as well.  Please restrict to CQs with "nonepl" keyword.  Notation will be required to indicate that if there is a third party contribution that does not appear on the list because it is mistakenly* marked as EPL
column9: project to notify IP Team.  IP Team will correct the relevant record.\n\n*e.g. nonepl project hosted on Sourceforge
column10: but released under the EPL
column11:
so the committer understandably entered EPL keyword in IPZilla...which would be in error in this context.
 
4)  Pending Contribution Questionnaires
We like it!  It would be useful for the project to confirm if these submissions are not required for the release.    
 
5) Other
Add section to allow projects to include any additional information they may wish to include (free form)'

column7: b'+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #252798 +++\n\nAll plug-ins must correctly list their required JVM versions in the manifest.mf. See the wiki page about selecting the correct JVM.'

b'+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #252799 +++\n\nProjects must use signed plugins using the Eclipse certificate. Exceptions must be authorized by the planning council for technical reasons.'

b"+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #252800 +++\n\nProjects must use jar'ed plug-ins (with unpack=false) unless authorized by the planning council for technical reasons. Nested jars should be avoided if possible since it creates problems for projects that has dependencies to such plug-ins. The OSGi runtime is fine with it but the compiler is not able to handle classpaths that contain nested jars. In case only one nested jar exists
column8: it is often better to expand the contents of that jar into the root folder (i.e. unnest the jar). If a plug-in contains large files that are frequently used (opened and closed)
column9: a jar'ed plug-in might degrade performance significantly since the file must be decompressed each time it is opened."

b'Created attachment 185116 [details]
Patch v.0.1

org.eclipse.core.internal.preferences.EclipsePreferences.toString() initializes cachedPath if toString() is called before the object is initialized by constructor. This happens only when running in debug mode if you add a breakpoint at the beginning of the constructor to see current values of fields and then open Variables view to see those values. Variables view calls Object.toString() to show some nice string representation of objects and it changes not initialized cachedPath to "/". Then it is no longer possible for the constructor to set correct value of cachedPath as absolutePath() initializes this field once only. In my case I was able to add preferences with path "/" as a child of preferences "/project".

This is a blocker as we are not able to debug the code safely as it may change unexpectedly state of objects showing inappropriate results. toString() should not initialize the object in any way as it is mainly used for debug purposes. Adding a breakpoint inside toString() will not help as this method is called by host Eclipse instance. You may add some System.out.println() calls to see that this method is in use.

You will not see the problem when running normally (not in debug mode) as you will not have any reference to the object before the constructor returns so you will not be able to call toString() for the object.

Attached patch solves the problem.'

b'Defining aspects using aop.xml causes recursion during AspectJAdaptor initialization which is caught by the existing protection and an exception thrown. The problem is caused by defining classes which may cause dependent classes to be loaded before the adaptor has finished initializing. Solution could be to provide a GeneratedClassHandler.'
b"BundleInfo#equals uses java.io.File to perform platform-specific equality testing of the bundle file location. However
column8: the hashCode method just uses the location string. This means a BundleInfo stored in a map or set cannot be correctly retrieved when the location differs for example in case or slashes.  This can cause uninstall to fail to update the bundles.info file because it doesn't find the bundle to remove from the list."

column7:
b"AK (5/23/01 7:42:33 PM)
 CodeFormatterPreferencePage should not hold on to the propertyStore it gets in the initDefaults method
 (or cut the link somewhere)
 a lot of memory cannot be freed because of this

NOTES:
EG (5/28/01 4:59:36 PM)
 The CodeFormatterPreferencePage has life cycle is the same as the workbench. 
 It should be an instance variable not a static variable.

AK (5/29/01 2:52:31 PM)
 this does make a differnce - the class keeps links to things it should not.
 the link is static so it is _never_  released. all the stuff that can be reached from that point will consequently be _never_ freed
 and that's a lot of memory as i saw.

EG (18.07.2001 15:34:24)
 review the code for potential memory leaks and misuse of static instead of instance variables.

MA (09.08.2001 15:19:11)
 reviewed and cleaned up code (200)"

b'I have been profiling the workbench to determine why the Perspective | Open 
action takes
so long to run.  The profiling revealed that 90% of the time is spent in the 
creation of view
widgets.  In the java perspective over 50% of the time is spent creating the 
parts for the
packages view and hierarchy view.

In my test scenario there are no resources in the workspace.  However
column8:
the 
createPartControl
method for the Hierarchy View takes 4.6s to run.    The createPartControl 
method for the Package view takes .87s to run.  
This is also surprising
column9: given that there are no resources in the workspace.  \nIn comparison
column10:
the createPartControl method for most of the other views is completed in .2 
to .3s.  

Here are the stats.

  RootLayoutContainer.createControl started
   PartPane.createControl Navigator finished in 311 ms
   PartPane.createControl Hierarchy finished in 4326 ms
   PartPane.createControl Packages finished in 872 ms
   PartPane.createControl Tasks finished in 250 ms
   PartPane.createControl Search Results finished in 271 ms
   PartPane.createControl Console finished in 210 ms
   PartPane.createControl Outline finished in 241 ms
  RootLayoutContainer.createControl finished in 7701 ms

Note: This profiling was done on top of VaJava.  However
column11:
it illustrates that
these views are way out of proportion in comparison to other views.

 AK please add a trace of this scenario. It was already on our list.

please see comments

column7:
b'1. Create a new project.
2. File-->Import-->Zip File.  Specify a jar that just has class files.
3. Now select all the packages in your new project and try to delete them.  Nothing happens - the
 packages are not removed.  Select an individual package.  Try to delete it.  It is not removed.
 The only way to get rid of the packages is in the Resources View.  Is this the intent???

4. File-->Import-->Zip File.  Specify the jar in Step 2.  Make sure overwrite without warning is checked.
 At one point I got duplicate packages.  Cannot recreate the duplication problem.  Not sure what
 state I was in.  I was going back and forth between the Java Perspective and the Resources
 Perspective.

NOTES:
EG (24.07.2001 21:24:14) 
 there is a fix for 1.0 in build 127 for not being able to delete a package.
 need to verify that this addresses the problem.'

b'This is a fix candidate for 1.0

Changing the name of the top-level type of a CU followed by save prompts the 
user whether they want to rename the compilation unit as well.

The current implementation is problematic since the prompt is done inside the 
delta processing. As a consequence
column8:
when changing a type programmatically a 
dialog can show up as a side effect.

We have removed this behaviour in the 2.0 stream since the same effect can be 
achieved with the rename type refactoring.

Proposal is to remove this behaviour in the 1.0 stream as well (1.0 already has 
the rename type refactoring).'

column7:
b'The new IResource adapter aware contribution mechanism no longer require us to 
make property page contributions for:
Team 
Info 
Project references'

b'JavaElementContentProvider (API) extends BaseJavaElementContentProvider
implements IElementChangedListener

There are several API issues.
- JavaElementContentProvider is API
column8:
BaseJavaElementContentProvider not.
- Why do we expose the IElementChangedListener as API? This is very 
PackageExplorer specific code.

My suggestion is:
JavaElementContentProvider in the API should be what is 
BaseJavaElementContentProvider now.
The package viewer should subclass this and add the IElementChangedListener 
functionality.'

column7:
b'Build I20020115. Autobuild on.
I started the debugger an then the IDE was frozen.

It looks like during the refresh of the type hierachy (which takes place in a
modal contex) another modal operation is started.

See the appended stack dumps for more details.'

Maximize and Move are possible.
With open dialog hung also all other windows of eclipse.

I must kill Eclipse do end the dialog (end eclipse).
All changes in the preferences are lost (a early pressed "apply" don't help)

I use eclipse-gtk 20020125.
The problem doesn't exists in the motif-version.'

column7: b'I am opening this PR because an older PR containing this problem was just \nmarked resolved/worksforme
column8:
which is not entirely accurate. The older PR is: 
http://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=3750
It is ok to close the older PR because the menu ordering problem has been 
corrected
column9:
but the "missing menu items" problem is still very much there.

As of 20020214-Stable build:

Go To -> Type... is missing from the Hierarchy view
Open With -> is missing from Class in Packages view
Copy Names is missing from the Hierarchy view
Cut is missing from CU in Packages view
Move is missing from Type in Packages and in Hierarchy view
 (should be able to move the type or the whole CU)
Run/Debug is missing from the Hierarchy view
But the most important missing thing from any Type is *all* of the TEAM 
functions
column10: including the whole Team -> menu
column11: and team items in the Compare \nWith -> menu
column12:
and Replace With -> menu.

I will paste a bitmap of 3 menus side-by-side so that you can easily see where 
the gaps are. In this diagram
column13: the menu on the left is the CU menu in the \nPackages view
column14: the menu in the middle is the Type menu in the Packages view
column15: \nand the menu on the right is the Type menu in the Hierarchy view. Ideally
column16:
all 
menus on Types and CUs in all perspectives should be analyzed in this visual 
manner - I have not used the new VAJ perspective much yet (waiting for the 
types to be displayed in a hierarchy) so I did not analyze those menus
column17:
but I 
suspect strongly that we will discover inconsistencies and gaps if we look.

Please
column18: if you don\'t do anything else
column19:
add team support to Types. This was done 
in VAME and it made a huge difference. There is less mental and actual context 
switch required. The current implementation in Eclipse reveals that there is a 
framework behind everything
column20: and we do not want to let this show. The user \nshould have a seamless experience without so many context switches. The 90% \ncase is that the CU/Type ratio is 1:1. In the other 10% case
column21: the tools should \nbe able to figure out what the user meant

b'3 of the JDT viewers update labels very slowly when they get a 
labelProviderChanged event from the DecoratorManager.

using the large workbench provided for Bug 10903 the following ContentViewers 
took a large amount of time to process labelProviderChanged for a very simple 
decorator (I have one that appends the currentTimeMilliseconds to the label and 
does nothing to the image).

ProblemTreeViewer (sometimes upwards of 500 ms)
JavaOutlineViewer (around 200 ms)
MethodsViewer (around 200ms)

This can potentially cause a large delay in update due to the amount of updates 
being sent by the CVS decorator (see Bug 12315).'

b'Build 20020326

The implementation of DocumentAdapter#close() prevents it from ever being 
closed (logic on null check against fDocument is wrong).

Therefore
column8: such buffers will leak in the JavaModel buffer manager.'

column8:

an exception.

The exception text will be attached to this report.'

column7:
b'M5 and build 20020425

PackageExplorerPart.saveExpansionState should be changed to use 
getVisibleExpandedElements() instead of getExpandedElements().
This is a huge startup performance win
column8: and is low risk.\nWithout it
column9: performance bogs down the more items have been expanded
column10: even \nacross shutdown and restart.\nThese extra items also have to get decorated
column11:
which is expensive for CVS and 
ClearCase decorators.

For more context see the 2002-04-13 01:43 comments in bug 7322.'

b"Build 20020611 + latest org.eclipse.ui from HEAD + all other projects imported 
as binary from 20020611

While launching the target
column8: the CPU went to 0 before the target had opened any \nwindows
column9: but it was still running.\nStopped threads in the debugger and saw that main and a reconciler thread were \ndeadlocked
column10:
as follows.  
I've included the indexing thread only to show that it was not involved in the 
deadlock.

The main thread is waiting on a WorkingCopy held by the JavaReconciler thread 
(acquired in JavaReconcilingStrategy.reconcile()
column11:
before doing the syncExec).
The JavaReconciler thread is waiting on the UI lock.
The syncExec in ProblemAnnotation's constructor is there to obtain the image 
for the marker.
This is a recent change for bug 18936.

column7: b'+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #225555 +++\n\nTM 3.0 has been released
column8: and TCF should work on top of the new APIs.'

column7: b'Another year
column8:
another request to update the URL for JBoss Tools Server Adapters.

Affected file: plugins/org.eclipse.wst.server.discovery/serverAdapterSites.xml

Suggested patch is as follows:

-   <site url="http://download.jboss.org/jbosstools/updates/webtools/neon/"/>
+   <site url="http://download.jboss.org/jbosstools/updates/webtools/oxygen/"/>

Thanks!

Marking as critical
column9: as without this our Oxygen stuff won\'t be exposed in Web Tools (instead you\'ll offer the Neon stuff for install into Oxygen
column10:
which won't go well).

(issue is a clone of last year's one asking the same thing for Mars: bug 4584041)

Downstream issue: https://issues.jboss.org/browse/JBIDE-24080'

column7: b'+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #252792 +++\n\nProjects must have a written ramp down policy by M6+0
column8: linked in the table above pending inclusion of ramp down element in the XML project plan. (One of the issues identified with this guideline is that its not so much the ramp down policy of how many votes are needed for each bug fix that we need to be consistent on
column9: but rather the meaning of each of the milestones and release candidates. See Platform 3.4 Endgame plan as a guideline. See also Galileo Final Daze.)'

column7: b'+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #252793 +++\n\nProjects must have their IP approved (a normal Eclipse requirement) and will follow the Eclipse Legal deadlines to do so. See also bug 220977.'
b'+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #252794 +++\n\nProjects should leverage only published APIs of dependencies. As a Release Review requirement
column8: deviations should be listed as part of a migration plan
column9: with bugs listed where APIs need to be provided by dependent projects.'

column7: b'+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #252795 +++\n\nProjects must use Eclipse message bundles unless there are technical reasons not to. (see Message Bundle Conversion Tool and [1])'
b"+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #252797 +++\n\nAll plug-ins (bundles) must use the true bundle form. That is
column8: provide a manifest.mf file
column9: and not rely on the plugin.xml file being 'translated' into a manifest.mf file at initial startup. See bug 130598. With that
column10: empty plugin.xml files in the presence of a manifest.mf file should not be included in a bundle."

column7: b'+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #252798 +++\n\nAll plug-ins must correctly list their required JVM versions in the manifest.mf. See the wiki page about selecting the correct JVM.'

b'+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #252799 +++\n\nProjects must use signed plugins using the Eclipse certificate. Exceptions must be authorized by the planning council for technical reasons.'
b'+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #252801 +++\n\nProjects must have build process maturity: scripted
column8: repeatable
column9: and executable by others.'

column7: b"+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #252803 +++\n\nAny new third-party plug-ins that are common between projects must be consumed via Orbit; the final Galileo release will not have duplicate third-party libraries (note that this only applies to identical versions of the libraries; thus if project A requires foo.jar 1.6 and project B uses foo.jar 1.7
column8: that's ok)."

column7: b'+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #252804 +++\n\nProjects must optimize their own update site using pack200 to reduce bandwidth utilization and provide a better update experience for users. With the introduction of p2
column8: project update sites must generate metadata (artifact and content repository info).'

column7: b'+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #252807 +++\n\nEach project will provide basic capability/activity definitions to allow for their UI contributions to be hidden. These must be provided in a separate plugin/feature to facilitate inclusion/exclusion by consumers in product development.'
b'+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #252808 +++\n\nThe project participates in Babel
column8: meaning it is registered and available for string translation
column9: etc.'

column7: b'/agent/executable/version.h defines a 9.0-DEV version. Mihini is in incubation and therefore its version should be 0.x.\n"READYAGENT" should also be renamed into "AGENT"
column8: or "MIHINIAGENT"
column9: since  ReadyAgent is not supposed to be used in the Mihini context.'

column7: b'Two 3rd party libraries have not meet the Eclipse IP policies: LibToMath et LibCryptom.\n\n- Remove the source code
column8:
- Find a solution:
 -- Use a new Library
 -- Implement the required features
 -- ...'

column7: b'one advantage to have a synchronous call to srvcon.connect() when flushing a policy is to have the result of data pushing to srv.\nFor now the result of srvcon.connect() is discarded. \nThe result should be pushed to Flush users (i.e. to triggerpolicy callers through EMP)'
b"If a lot of data are pushed to a lot of different paths/supports at a rapid pace
column8: an excessive amount of resource might be reserved by stagedb (one table per path/support combination). This is especially true of large and deeply nested table structures
column9: such as big ReadNode results.\n\nThere must be a more direct way to send such data
column10: presumably through some almost direct AWTDA encoding + SendData. \n\nIt might also be appropriate
column11: if there's an API dedicated to sending huge unstructured data
column12: to let it handle regular flushes to the server.\n\nAn alternative would be to buffer those unsent data packets in flash/filesystem."

column7: b'When several diagrams have been open
column8: there is no real way to close them all in one command.\nIn fact
column9: you can use the "file>closeAll" command but it closes both the editors and the model itself which is not what we want.\nwe would like to closes all diagrams but keep the model explorer open on the model.\nso
column10: a "closeAll" command available next to the "close" command in the multi-editor would be appreciated'

column7: b'A context menu action can launch the diagram and model validation.'
b'When searching for eclipse terms in google there are broken links to the forum. For example
column8:
searching for the term:

headless workspace eclipse

gives a link to a forum article. This link points to this address

http://dev.eclipse.org/newslists/news.eclipse.webtools/msg13095.html

However
column9:
when you click on it it redirects you to this page:

http://www.eclipse.org/forums/index.php?t=thread&frm_id=88

The search term does not appear on this page. 

This is a frustrating. It appears to happen to all the Google links to the forum.

can this be fixed?'

column7: b'Posts Posted on the Forum occur in the newsgroups but not the forum itself.\n(see tmf newsgroups for an example)'

2] on https://www.eclipse.org/forums/index.php/f/259/ but my replies to don't show up yet I did not get a error/warning.

column7:
b'the multiple meanings of the "non-epl" keyword is misleading.  It seems to be related to both the license and the origin of the contribution.  From the keyword definition in IPzilla
   non-epl = Contribution is non-EPL or third-party packages only.

The new CQ workflow does not clarify the matter.  People are give two choices:
- EPL and written by Eclipse projects members (project member is a Committer or an active participant who contributes code through Bugzilla)

- Not EPL and/or written by a 3rd party. If your non-EPL contribution contains nested components
column8: please list each nested component individually in the list of packages.\n\nIn the case of EPL
column9: what is the point of the "active participant who contributes code through Bugzilla" characterization?  Who defines "active"?  Isn\'t the fact that the person is contributing code that warrants a CQ enough to say that they are active?\n\nIn the non-epl case the wording of the first sentence is ambiguous.  While I understand that the "Not" applies only to "EPL"
column10: it could be construed as applying to the "and/or written by a 3rd party" part.  More significantly and in light of the EPL section
column11:
the definition of third party is unclear.  

The way I read this now is as follows:
Q1: is this EPL or not EPL
Q2: is the contribution from a random place that has nothing to do with Eclipse or from someone who is actually involved with Eclipse.

This separates the concerns (licensing and origin) and distinguishes between
column12: for example
column13: stuff from Apache and people who are actualy trying to get involved in Eclipse.'

column7:
b'Steps to reproduce:
        1. Download the RAP Demo from CVS.

"SoapConnectorThreadPool : 1819" daemon prio=5 tid=0x12b0dc0  
nid=0x945 runnable [0xd457e000..0xd4581a00]

From development: we think that the thread safety should be in the emf core
column8: \nbut to a limit.  Thread safety should be ensured for read access only.  \nFor write access
column9:
it is up to the application developer to ensure thread
safety.                                                                 
We propose that EMF be modified to synchronize the load and             
getContents methods or ResourceImpl.   

The issue has been reported on Sun Solaris but is applicable to all OS'

column7:
b'Using a slightly modified library schema for this example (added an attribute 
to Book).  Here's the xsd file corresponding to the example:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<xsd:schema targetNamespace="http://www.example.eclipse.org/Library"
    xmlns:ecore="http://www.eclipse.org/emf/2002/Ecore"
    xmlns:lib="http://www.example.eclipse.org/Library"
    xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema">
  <xsd:complexType name="Book">
    <xsd:sequence>
      <xsd:element name="title" type="xsd:string"/>
      <xsd:element name="pages" type="xsd:int"/>
      <xsd:element name="category" type="lib:BookCategory"/>
      <xsd:element name="author" type="xsd:anyURI"
          ecore:reference="lib:Writer" ecore:opposite="books"/>
    </xsd:sequence>
    <xsd:attribute name="catAttr" type="lib:BookCategory"/>
  </xsd:complexType>
  <xsd:complexType name="Writer">
    <xsd:sequence>
      <xsd:element name="name" type="xsd:string"/>
      <xsd:element maxOccurs="unbounded" minOccurs="0" name="books"
          type="xsd:anyURI" ecore:reference="lib:Book" ecore:opposite="author"/>
      <xsd:element maxOccurs="1" minOccurs="0" name="favoriteBook"
          type="xsd:anyURI" ecore:reference="lib:Book" ecore:opposite="author" 
ecore:transient="true"/>
    </xsd:sequence>
  </xsd:complexType>
  <xsd:complexType name="Library">
    <xsd:sequence>
      <xsd:element name="name" type="xsd:string"/>
      <xsd:element maxOccurs="unbounded" minOccurs="0"
          name="writers" type="lib:Writer"/>
      <xsd:element maxOccurs="unbounded" minOccurs="0"
          name="books" type="lib:Book"/>
    </xsd:sequence>
  </xsd:complexType>
  <xsd:simpleType name="BookCategory">
    <xsd:restriction base="xsd:NCName">
      <xsd:enumeration value="Mystery"/>
      <xsd:enumeration value="ScienceFiction"/>
      <xsd:enumeration value="Biography"/>
    </xsd:restriction>
  </xsd:simpleType>  
</xsd:schema>

In the above schema
column8: 'catAttr' attribute in Book doesn't have a default value specified in the schema. The generated BookImpl class has the following code though: /** * The default value of the '{@link #getCatAttr() Cat Attr}' attribute. * * * @see #getCatAttr() * @generated * @ordered */ protected static final BookCategory CAT_ATTR_EDEFAULT = BookCategory.MYSTERY_LITERAL; I would have expected CAT_ATTR_EDEFAULT to have a null value.'

b'+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #252813 +++\n\nEach major project (the top-level projects except for the Tools and Technology projects where it is the sub-projects) should have an About dialog icon and contribute to the welcome page.'
b"If ServiceModelManager.getConfiguration() is called prior to the org.eclipse.ptp.services.core plugin being loaded
column8: Eclipse will attempt to load the plugin and call the plugin's start() method. This will call ServiceModelManager.loadModelConfiguration() to try and load the saved model state.\n\nThe problem is that loadModelConfiguration() eventually calls IConfigurationElement.createExecutableExtension() which (for unknown reasons) terminates the start() method. getConfiguration() then returns null because the model hasn't been loaded. I don't know why start() is terminated
column9: but it must be something to do with the class loader logic.\n\nThe attached patch attempts to address this problem by moving the model loading out of the plugin start() method. Now any time a model-related method on ServiceModelManager is called
column10: it will make sure the model is loaded first. Unfortunately this breaks some tests which assume that localModelConfiguration() will replace the existing configuration with a new one.\n\nIf anyone can think of a better way to fix the problem
column11: please feel free.\n\nThis is a critical bug because it breaks saving/restoring resource manager state."

b"The problem is as follows:

Thumbnail is listening (via UpdateListener) an UpdateManager and handles
notifyPainting event. If the thumbnail's source figure is about to be painted
column8:
the thumbnail asks for repainting:

(class Thumbnail)
public void notifyPainting(Rectangle damage
column10: int y
column11: int w
column12: int h) {\n if (isVisible())\n  getUpdateManager().addDirtyRegion(this
column13: x
column14: y
column15: w
column17:
dirtyRegions);
  dirtyRegions.clear();
 }

 ... 
}

We can see that the code flow is as follows:

0. something changed in the thumbnail's source figure
1. repairDamage is called (DeferredUpdateManager)
2. firePainting is called (DeferredUpdateManager)
 2.1. notifyPainting is called (Thumbnail)
 2.2. repaint is called (Figure)
 2.3. addDirtyRegion is called (DeferredUpdateManager) - this add an item in
dirtyRegiods field
6. a statement dirtyRegions.clear() is executed

We can see that even if the thumbnail asks for repainting
column19:
because dirtyRegions field
is cleared.

The path proposal will be in the following bugzilla comment."

column7: b'Up to now
column8: creation of new items is only possible via the context menu. We should enhance the example to provide a palette
column9: which allows some prototype-based creation through drag-and-drop. In contrast to GEF 3.x the palette should render a minimized version of the actual element visualizations rather than providing icons.'

column7: b'Currently
column8: a content part is only selectable if an interaction policy is bound that selects that part
column9: and a content part is only focusable if an interaction policy is bound that focuses that part. However
column10: when implementing an interaction policy that is not bound per part
column11: but instead
column12: for example
column13: only once on the root part
column14: and this interaction policy should focus or select a content part
column15: then the focusability and selectability cannot be managed via the bindings anymore. Therefore
column16: a mechanism should be provided to query the selectability and focusability of a content part.'

column7: b'Currently
column8: some focus and selection changes are carried out by operations that are executed on the operation history (i.e. undoable)
column9: and some changes are directly applied to the FocusModel and SelectionModel (i.e. not undoable). Either all of the changes should be undoable
column10: or none of them should be undoable.'

column7: b'As a prerequisite for bug #487081 (using Graphviz executable for layouting in DOT.UI) and #440098 (enable using ELK for layouting in Zest)
column8: we should the layout adoption within Zest.FX as follows:\n\nWe should ensure that the visualization and interaction within Zest is not dependent on the layout interfaces (or attributes defined therein)
column9: but only on Zest attributes. In the context of DOT.UI (in which the layout information in the Graph could already be provided through the Graphviz executable
column10: we would need to remove all GEF4 Layout dependencies and only rely on the Graph-adoption alone). In the context of ELK
column11: this would allow us to properly convert between the layout info of ELK (instead of our own) and the Graph layout data. In detail
column12: the refactoring has to comprise:\n\n1) We have to define Zest layout properties that can be used to specify position and size of nodes as well as routing of edges. The Zest content parts should listen to changes of these properties alone for refreshing their visuals
column13: and the transaction policies should only update these properties (so that the graph model could also be stored persistet).\n\nAs Graphviz uses control points to describe the positioning of edges and we may use waypoints in other scenarios
column14: we should simple provide "points" for edges and leave the concrete interpretation to the connection router (ZestProperties.CONNECTION_ROUTER). \n\n2) We need to ensure that the attributes of the layout adapters and the graph model elements are no longer bidirectionally bound
column15: but that instead the layout information attributes are bidirectionally updated/converted upon changes. The layout algorithms should rely on the Layout properties only
column16: the visualization and transactions in zest should only relay on the Zest attributes.'

column7: b'The trait is null.  Should this trait be coming from the common-attributes group

column7: b'Tests using taglib metadata EMF models are failing randomly in 3.0.1
column8: with some tests failing more often than others.   Examination of logs hint at unexpected loading issues that appear to be caused either by unthread-safe code
column9:
or problems in the underlying EMF code itself under some condition.

Here is what we know:
 - Metadata model code has not changed in 3.0.1.   In fact
column10: for the most part
column11:
it is unchanged since Europa release.
 - EMF plugin in 3.0.0 is same as 3.0.1
 - We have not seen a failure while operating normally; failures seem to occur randomly in automated tests only
 - tests are not failing while debugging
 - tests do not fail every time while running.   Sometimes a test must be run many times before a failure occurs.
 - Nearly all tests loading metadata are loading the same model.   JSF H and F tag metadata.   This metadata has not changed in 3.0.1.

column7:
b'Eclipse 3.6 RC1 hangs when you edit xhtml files if you add *.xhtml to JSP Content:
Unhandled event loop exception
java.lang.StackOverflowError


Follow this steps to replicate de error:
1 - create a xhtm facelets page;
2 - close the recent created file;
2 - goto Windows - Preference - Geral - Content Type - JSP
column8:
than add *.xhtml
3 - try to edit the xhtml file again and eclipse will hang giving the erro message 

Unhandled event loop exception
java.lang.StackOverflowError

4 - facelet validator tooling will also freeze.
5 - undo the Content Type association and everything will work again.

This Content Type association is necessary to enable jsf EL  in xhtml files.
It works in eclipse 3.5.'

column7: b'This is my first bug report
column8:
so I apologise if I'm doing something wrong.

When I was working on a C++ project I accidentally clicked on a folder and
dragged
column9: even though I didn\'t want to move it anywhere. Not knowing exactly what\nI should do
column10: I placed the cursor back over the folder I had clicked on
column11: since\nusually this gives a "destination same as source" error and doesn\'t do any\ndamage. In any case
column12: the predicted error message did come up but instead of\ndoing no damage
column13: my entire project was deleted
column14: including the files on disk.\n\nActually
column15: now I think I might have moved the Project folder into one of it\'s\ncontained folders. In any case
column16: I lost about 2 hours of work and if I wasn\'t\nusing cvs it would have been much much worse.'

column7: b'In order to move away from the current 2-parse search architecture
column8:
we need to
start storing more information from the initial index that will allow search to
process search requests from the index alone. 

As a first pass we need to:

- change index storage format to accommodate index bit fields
- add match location (whether the match is in the acutal file or if it is in a 
  included file)
- add offsets to index'
