column7: b'When an element has a settable container feature
column8: undo/redo behavior of an Add \nto a container element produces incorrect results.  In particular
column9: when redo \nis attempted
column10:
the element is appended to the end of the containment collection 
and then moved some seemingly arbitrary amount upwards.  The original index of 
this element is not respected or restored on redo of the add.

Setup of scenario (using org.eclipse.uml2 as an example):

1. Create an Interaction
2. Add multiple CombinedFragments the fragments collection of the Interaction.
3. Add an InteractionOccurrence to the beginning of the fragments collection.
4. Undo/redo the add in step 3.

Notice the InteractionOccurrence is not replaced at the beginning of the 
fragments collection as expected.

This seems to be because MSL is receiving events for both the set of the 
enclosingInteraction feature of the InteractionOccurrence and for the add of 
the InteractionOccurrence to the fragments collection of the Interaction.  
When the add is redone
column11: the redo of the Set appends the InteractionOccurrence \nto the fragments list.  The redo of the add to the fragments collection is \nthen executed.'

column7:
b'The following are some of the requirements addressed by this enhancement:
1)EMFT API - Provide a model management layer to replace the current MSL API 
in the GMF run-time. It will consist of at least two layers:  a non-Eclipse 
core
column8: providing primarily the "transaction model"
column9:
and an Eclipse workbench 
integration layer.
2)Multi-threading - Implement a protocol for clients to read and write EMF 
models on multiple threads.  The protocol will not be optional
column10: and compliance \nwill be enforced as much as is possible.  Both writing and reading are \nserialized (not concurrent)
column11: to protect structural integrity of the EMF \nmodels
column12: including explicit and implicit changes (e.g.
column13:
proxy resolution) and 
dependent infrastructures such as cross-reference indices.
3)Model Integrity - Semantic integrity is ensured by automatic validation to 
detect invalid changes and semantic procedures to proactively maintain 
correctness of semantic dependencies.  Validation constraints and semantic 
procedures can be added to the system by clients.  They are triggered by three 
different mechanisms:  EMF adapter notification
column14: transaction pre-commit \n(was "live" mode in MSL)
column15: "manually" by the client (was "batch" mode).\n4)Batched Events - Clients are notified of groups of related changes in \nbatches
column16: rather than as a stream of EMF notifications.  In particular
column17: this \nallows applications to analyze change sets in their entirety.  Moreover
column18:
listeners must have a well-defined "safe" way to make dependent changes to the 
model (this is related to the "semantic procedures" of item 2). Clients can 
listen for only certain events of interest to them using an efficient 
filtering mechanism.
5)Undo/Redo - For a simplified programming model
column19:
the framework automatically 
tracks changes applied to models without the need for client code to use EMF 
edit Commands.  These changes are encapsulated in transactions/operations that 
can undo and redo themselves.  Managed changes include both object-level and 
resource-level changes (e.g
column20: create
column22: unload). Clients may also use EMF \ncommands
column23:
and both styles are supported in the same editing domain.
6)Editing Domain - Support cooperative editing of models by multiple 
editors/applications.  EMF resources can be shared amongst different editing 
domains. An open question is whether objects/resources need to be traceable to 
a single originating/owning editing domain.
7)Reference Management - Enhance the EMF's dynamic reverse-reference mapping 
to support:
a) more advanced querying/filtering on reverse references
b) delegation of reverse-reference lookup to pluggable index providers (such 
as a workspace index for unloaded resources)
c) Note that this should include support for cross-editing-domain references 
as per item 5.
8)Object Destruction - Support for "destroying" objects by removing them from 
a resource and severing all references to them
column24:
with undo/redo and model 
integrity support (validation to prevent incorrect destruction and semantic 
procedures to apply dependent changes). Note that this should include support 
for cross-editing-domain references as per item5.
9)Protocol Escapes - Some clients occasionally have a need to work outside of 
the normal resource management protocol.  The API needs to provide the means 
to apply model changes that are:
  not validated
  not enhanced by semantic procedures
  not recorded for undo/redo
  not sent to listeners
  performed during an otherwise read-only transaction
  or any combination thereof.  The framework does not guarantee 
the safety of any of these escapes; it is assumed that clients know what they 
are doing.
10) Eclipse Workspace - The framework provides traceability between EMF 
resources and workspace resources.  Multi-threaded access is coordinated via 
the Eclipse jobs API and its integration with the workspace. The framework 
also supports non-workspace resources (e.g.
column27:
or just anywhere on the filesystem or the network).
11) Eclipse Operations - The framework supports the Eclipse operation history 
as an undo stack for undo/redo (see item 4) of resource changes.  The API 
provides a framework for undoable operations that automatically capture 
undo/redo information
column28: which can be interleaved on the same history with \ndependent operations that do not modify the EMF model.  The client application \nprovides the operation history that an editing domain works with.'

column7: b'This enhancement addresses the following requirements:\n1) Analysis of what needs to be deprecated in the GMF MSL API and implementing the @deprecated tags with appropriate documentation.\n2)Re-implementation of the deprecated APIs as delegation to/extension of the EMF-TX and workbench APIs.  Goal is to pass all existing JUnits.'
b'The current implementation of EMFCoreUtil.destroy() recursively destroys contained elements.  However
column8: there can be other elements that have an existence dependency on the element being destroyed but are not contained.  It should be possible for a metamodel provider or a client application to indicate which other dependents should also be destroyed.'

column7: b'this use case had been encountered on the GMF side\nafter changing the canonical edit poilcy to start a wrtie transaction instead of an unprotected transaction
column8: then trying to undo we found that the canonical change does not get undon through the recorded command.\nThis blocks the invistigation we are doing to fix the undo/redo problems in the canonical edit policies.'

column7: b'The DeleteElementCommand disconnects cross-resource-contained objects from their eContainers but
column8: unfortunately
column9: it does not remove them from the contents of their eResource()s.  This results in the object not really being destroyed
column10: because it is still reachable from some resource.'

column7: b'As it stands
column8: a client cannot use the abort on error load options without violating the internal API because the load option itself called OPTION_ABORT_ON_ERROR is located inside the GMFResource class
column9: which is internal API.\n\nAlso
column10: clients should be able to access the internal AbortResourceLoadException class so that they could throw that exception as part of a ResourceHandler or an ExtendedMetaData in order to halt the resource loading process.'

column7:
b'The following deprecated internal API must be removed after they have been published in an integration build:

package org.eclipse.gmf.runtime.emf.core.internal.resources:
  - class GMFResource
  - class GMFHelper
  - class GMFHandler
  - class GMFLoad

package org.eclipse.gmf.runtime.emf.core.internal.exceptions:
  - the entire package (one class and one package.html)'
b'The PathmapManager only denormalizes file: and platform:/resource URI schemes.  As a result
column8: when I create a Resource (using ResourceSet.createResource(URI) method) for a pathmapped URI of a resource deployed in a bundle JAR
column9: it ends up having a different URI than I asked to be created
column10: and my application goes bonkers.\n\nThis happens because my pathmap://FOO/bar.xmi URI is normalized to jar:file:/path/to/eclipse/plugins/com.example_1.0.0.jar!/resources/bar.xmi but then denormalization fails because the jar:file: scheme is arbitrarily disallowed.  So
column11: instead of getting a resource with the pathmap URI
column12: I get a resource with the jar:file: URI.\n\nFor any pathmap: URI that the PathmapManager can normalize
column13: the PathmapManager *must* be able to denormalize it to restore the original pathmap: URI.'

column7: b'The org.apache.batik.* bundles and org.w3c.* bundles from the Batik collection must have qualifiers.'
b'Download Eclipse-SDK-3.4M4
column9: and look at the Java Build Path
column10: when you expand the org.apache.batik.transcoder plug-in dependency
column11: you will see the 9 access rules defined for org.apache.batik.transcoder. These are of course the 9 exported packages in org.apache.batik.transcoder.\n\nWhen you do the same above
column12: but with both orbits extracted
column13: the plug-in no longer compiles.\nWhen expanding the the org.apache.batik.transcoder plug-in dependency
column14: there are now only 5 exported packages in org.apache.batik.transcoder
column15: four packages are missing.\n\nI did a binary diff on the org.apache.batik.transcoder plug-in in both Orbit R200709171314 and Orbit S200712072116 and they are identical
column16:
except for the version number.
I cannot explain why having one of :
org.apache.batik.transcoder_1.6.0.v200706111724.jar
org.apache.batik.transcoder_1.6.0.v200711021015.jar
works fine but having both breaks.

This problem occurs when you download a recent GMF 2.1 integration build which has Orbit S200710221836 and WTP which has Orbit S200712072116. GMF depends on Batik for SVG support and as a result of this issue
column17: at runtime
column18:
we receive a bunch of:

java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: org.apache.batik.transcoder.Transcoder
   at java.lang.J9VMInternals.verifyImpl(Native Method)
   at java.lang.J9VMInternals.verify(Unknown Source)
   at java.lang.J9VMInternals.initialize(Unknown Source)
   at org.eclipse.gmf.runtime.draw2d.ui.render.awt.internal.svg.SVGImage.renderImage(Unknown Source)

As a workaround
column19: we are going to make sure that GMF adopts S200712072116 for GMF 2.1 M4 so that only one set of the Batik plug-ins are present.\n\nHowever
column20: this issue will cause GMF to break when someone uses update
column21: since the new and old batik will be present.'

b"Created attachment 100701 [details]
A patch to use constraint's descriptor as the key for getCurrentConstraintData() method

AbstractValidationContext class (in org.eclipse.emf.validation.internal.service package) used constraint's descriptor as key with its putCurrentConstraintData method
column10: you'll always get null when calling getCurrentConstraintData() even after you putCurrentConstraintData(...) successfully.  This is a regression defect."

column7: b'The release will be blocked until these legal about-file issues are resolved.\n\nThe summary in bug 234485 lists several occurrences in the Batik bundles (excluding PDF) of licenses referenced in the NOTICE file that are not referenced in the about.html.'

b"Build ID: HEAD: 1.3.0.I200811021725

Steps To Reproduce:
After looking at the code in LiveValidationListener
column8: I don't see how registeredClientContextIds can ever be initialized....\n\nWhen running live validation
column9:
NPE is thrown because registeredClientContextIds is null.


The null pointer exception is thrown because registeredClientContextIds is null. The only place to initialize registeredClientContextIds is from ::registerClientContextIDs method.  The only place ::registerClientContextIDs method is getting called is from IExtensiolnChangeHandler::addExtension method. However
column10: the first line of addExtension method checks if registeredClientContextIds is not null. If it is null
column11: then rest of the method will not be called. So based on my understanding
column12:
registeredClientContextIds will never getting initialized....

This is a regression. I believe that it is introduced when fixing bugzilla 137213. Please investigate and fix as soon as possible. 



More information:"

column7: b'The cause of build hangs in the nightly extra-plugins builds is a pop-up dialog from CDO when a transaction fails to commit because of a dangling reference.\n\nThe dangling reference is a reference to the "isAssociationEnd" query from the example UML EMF Facet query-set.  This example is not installed in the configuration in which the build runs tests
column8: so naturally the reference to the query is unresolvable.'

column7:
b"Kepler M6

The CDO transaction handler installed on the editor's transaction refreshes the edit-parts for objects being added to or modified in the transaction.  Not only is this not necessary (because GMF will update the edit-parts anyways) but it actually results in corruption of the ChangeDescription recorded for undo/redo.

Steps to reproduce:

1. Open a model that has some class in a class diagram.
2. In the Model Explorer
column8: delete the class.  See the class view disappear\n   form the diagram.  So far
column9:
so good.
3. Undo the deletion.
4. See only the top-level shape return (none of its compartments or other
   details) and an exception in the log reporting violation of the
   'no duplicates' constraint in the styles containment list of a shape in
   the diagram."

column7: b'Papyrus M6\n\nAfter applying a stereotype to an element in the model
column8: attempting to save the editor can fail with a "no write transaction" exception from GMF.  The reason is that the TransactionChangeRecorder detects the replacement of the dynamic package\'s factory (the package is in a resource in the resource set) when prepared for CDO compatibility.\n\nIt should be fairly straightforward to wrap the InternalCDOPackageRegistry::PackageProcessor in the session created by an IPapyrusRepository to create an unprotected write transaction (GMF-style) on the editing domain for the package\'s resource set.'

column7: b'The CDO-integration nightly tests are failing to build because the Buckminster RMAP is pulling the CDO builds from the 4.3 M1 milestone instead of the M2 milestone
column8: which is the milestone after the interim build that was used temporarily to satisfy the dependency on the org.eclipse.emf.cdo.server.ocl_4.2.0 bundle version.'

column7: b'This is a top-task for all memory-related optimizations.\n\nThere are still a lot of memory leaks in various Papyrus components (e.g. Outline
column8: ModelExplorer
column9: Properties View
column10: Specific diagrams
column11: Menus
column12: ...). These memory leaks can cause major performance degradation after a long usage of Papyrus.\n\nWhen an editor is closed
column13:
all elements related to this specific editor/model should be disposed. This includes:

- All Draw2D Figures
- All GMF EditParts
- All EMF EObjects
- ModelSet & Resources
- Editor & Nested editors

There exists many cross-references between all these elements. If a single element remains in Memory
column14: the whole graph cannot be garbage-collected
column15: resulting in major memory leak each time an editor is closed.'

b'Papyrus Mars RC1\n\nCollaborations are BehavioredClassifiers.  I find them very practical for definition of system behaviour as the context classifier for Interactions
column8: especially (communication and sequence diagrams).\n\nIn other kinds of classifier (e.g.
column9: Class)
column10: the Model Explorer\'s "New Diagram" context menu lets me create behaviour diagrams.  These create the appropriate kind of Behavior as the classifierBehavior
column11: which is exactly what I want as a user.  But in the Collaboration
column12: the only kind of diagram I can create is a Composite Structure Diagram.  To create a behaviour diagram I first have to create the particular Behavior and then create a diagram in it.  However
column13: because of bug 468169
column14:
I cannot access the Behavior that I created and so cannot create a diagram for it.

Steps to reproduce:

1. Create a Collaboration in a package in the Model Explorer.
2. Right-click on the Collaboration and see what the New Diagram menu offers.
3. Observe that the only choice is Composite Structure Diagram.
   ==> All the same diagrams supported for Classes should be available'

column7: b'Papyrus Mars post RC2
column8: commit 2aa0ccd22061a086cc0d309478df23b991d6c026 or later\n\nSince the resolution of bug 459701
column9: there are new test failures in some diagram tests for self-relationship links.  These tests make incorrect assertions via a generic test framework method that never previously worked.  That test framework was fixed by bug 459701
column10:
so now these tests need to be updated to assert what is actually (correctly) implemented in the diagrams.

b'Steps to reproduce:
1. Create a new model
2. Create a new composite structure diagram

b'Created attachment 261268 [details]
Model with corrupted diagram

There can be failure during undo of display-related operations
involving stereotyped elements
column8: due to the way "StereotypeComment" shapes and edges are now managed.\nFor instance
column9: if one displays several stereotyped connectors at once (<<BindingConnector>> in that case)
column10: using "Show all related links" on an IBD
column11: then select undo

the undo operation may fail with the following exceptions:

The ClassCastException is due to the fact that the dangling connector is rattached (semantically) to its owning block (a class
column15: instead of a connector). See .notation file at line 251.\n\nIt is very much likely that those failures are due to "unsafe" manipulation of the diagram\'s list of nodes and edges by the AppliedStereotypeCommentEditPolicy edit policy
column16: when adding/removing the invisible shape and edge for the stereotype-as-comment display.'

column7: b'Papyrus-RT implements UML-RT state machines that have sufficiently different behaviour and presentation that it is necessary to override certain edit-parts.  However
column8: as the Papyrus base implementation of the State Machine Diagram has an edit-provider at highest priority
column9: it is impossible for DSLs based on Papyrus to customize the edit-parts in this diagram.\n\nObviously
column10: the core implementation of a diagram should never have GMF service providers above Lowest priority.\n\nThis is a stop-ship problem for Papyrus-RT; UML-RT state machine diagrams are infeasible.'

column7: b"The UI can deadlock on the workspace model index when saving a model
column8:
in the case that a text editor is open on the UML resource (or whatever resources have changes to save).

The sequence is like so:

1. The UI thread invokes save.  This saves the UML resource to disk
   via the workspace resource framework.
2. The workspace starts notifying resource listeners.
3. The index manager processes resource deltas
column9:
scheduling jobs that
   are immediately blocked waiting for access to the affected projects
   (the files saved in these projects are still locked by the UI).
4. The text-file buffer infrastructure in the text editor processes
   resource deltas
column10:
during which it checks to see whether any text
   editors need to close as a result.  This process causes the
   workbench page to compare editors with inputs.
5. The PapyrusMatchingStrategy for editor inputs checks the index to
   find the root resource of whatever potential 'shard' resource is
   referenced by the editor input.
6. This blocks on the index
column11:
which isn't ready yet to provide an
   answer to the query because re-indexing jobs are pending.

This is a deadlock
column12: because the re-indexing jobs cannot proceed while the resource change notification is still in progress."

b'Papyrus RT 0.7.2.201609022000
Papyrus UML 2.0.1.201609061203
Eclipse  4.6.0.v20160606-1342

I have a Papyrus-RT installation based on the latest integration build of Papyrus 2.0.1
column8: which for some days now has not shown updates to label decorations of any kind on files in the Package Explorer.  This is annoying for development (not seeing git status of files
column9: seeing stale problem decorations
column10: etc.).\n\nHowever
column11: it also happens that the workbench hangs on attempt to open any Papyrus(-RT) model.  It turns out that the two problems are related
column12:
and caused by the Index Manager:  the label decoration update job and the workspace model index job are deadlocked on access to the static IndexManager instance at these call sites:

In the WorkspaceModelIndex::addListener() method:

 IndexManager.getInstance().addListener(this
column14: but it is now happening consistently in my Papyrus-RT installation.  At least one other developer has also reported not seeing label decorations.\n\nA slight re-arrangement of the code that initializes the IndexManager
column15: moving that startManager() call from the IndexManager class initializer to the job that creates the manager resolves the problem when installed in my Papyrus-RT workbench:  label decorations are normal and the Papyrus editor opens and seems to work.'

column7: b'In the Neon.2 release
column8: the org.eclipse.papyrus.uml.diagram.linklf bundle does not export any of its packages.  Not only is it standard practice (and required for Release Train projects) to export all public API packages
column9: and usually also internal API packages (with the internal warning marker)
column10: but Papyrus-RT state machine diagram needs to be able to override the graphical node edit-policy provided by Link LF.  In order to do this
column11: we need to be able to extend the DefaultLinksLFEditPolicy class
column12: which is not exported.'

column7: b"The Advanced tab for UML elements transforms the incoming selection from a diagram with too many assumptions about objects that actually are adaptable.\n\nThe UMLPropertySection::transformSelection(Object) method doesn't attempt to object EObject adapters from IAdaptables except as a last resort
column8: when the usual pattern in Papyrus is to attempt this adaptation first.  In particular
column9: the handling of EditParts by obtaining the semantic element directly from the notation view doesn't account for special edit-part semantic adaptation as in Papyrus-RT
column10: where the view references the root definition of elements that are inherited.\n\nConsequently
column11: for inherited elements in Papyrus-RT
column12: the Advanced properties shows the properties of the wrong element
column13: so that any redefinition is not apparent.  It is difficult or impossible for Papyrus-RT to replace the Advanced properties contribution of the Papyrus UML Diagram Common layer
column14: so this misadaptation needs to be fixed in Papyrus."

column7: b"Papyrus master commit a8a5132378e073d038d8f72efe8b4ac01587567a (3 May 2017)\n\nIt was not sufficient to ensure that the Papyrus p2 repository distributes the XWT Ecore model bundle (bug 508843) to ensure that cross references from Sections in Properties Context models can resolve objects in XWT resources.  The Papyrus-RT Tooling JUnit tests are still failing with run-time exceptions
column8: being failure to cast the AnyTypeImpls loaded instead of the proper XWT UI model to the Composite type.\n\nThe root cause is that the context resource loaded from a URI with ppe: scheme has
column9: via relative HREFs
column10: proxy references to XWT resources also using ppe: scheme.  Because the PropertiesCatalog resource factory registered against this scheme always creates PropertiesXMIResource instances
column11: the outcome predicted by the TODO comment in that class occurs:  the XWT XML resource registered by the now published bundle against the 'xwt' file extension is not create because the URI scheme factory registration has precedence."

column7: b'+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #252813 +++\n\nEach major project (the top-level projects except for the Tools and Technology projects where it is the sub-projects) should have an About dialog icon and contribute to the welcome page.'

b'Now they reference TextCompartmentEditPart directly so the solution is to add \nan interface to decouple them.'

column7:
b'1. Create "JUnit" java project as explained in the JD Users guide
2. Import junit37src.jar file 
3. Expand JUnit->junit.samples.money.
4. Select Money.java and drag it over junit.framework
5. A dialog pops up requesting to preview or finish refactoring the code
6. Select Preview
column8:
a Refactoring dialog is shown with the necessary code changes
7. Review the code changes and select "Finish"
8. Eclipse crashes with...

Error: Could'nt find per display information

Not reviewing the code and selecting "Finish" works fine. Necesary code changes
are seen without any errors

Eclipse drop: Version 2.0(pre-release)
column9: March 21
column10:
2002
OS: IBM AIX 4.3.3 (Maintenance level package: 4.3.3.0.09)

Desktop: AIX CDE v1.0.3 
Motif: 2.1.0'

column7: b'No FocusEvent comes in Linux (Red Hat 7.2).\n\nCombo test = new Combo(parent
b'- File -> New -> Project\n- Plug-in Development -> Plug-in Project
column8: Next\n- set Project Name = asdf
column9: Next
column10: Next\n- click Create a new plug-in using... radio\n- select Hello World
column11: Next
column12: Finish\n- expand the new project in the Navigator
column13:
including the contained src/asdf tree
- hold CTRL and select in this order: .classpath and asdfPlugin.java
- right-click -> Open
- get the attached dump after a few seconds'

column7:
b'integration build 0423

- start in the Resource perspective
- File -> New -> Project
- Plug-in Development -> Plug-in Project
column8: Next\n- set Project Name = asdf
column9: Next
column10: Next\n- click Create a new plug-in using... radio\n- select Hello World
column11: Next
column12: Finish\n- close the auto-opened plugin.xml editor\n- expand the new project in the Navigator
column13:
including the contained src/asdf tree
- hold CTRL and select in this order: asdfPlugin.java and .classpath
- right-click -> Open
- get the attached SWT error'

b'Bug: Path variable name can not contain GB18030 characters in Eclipse for Linux.

Language: Simplified Chinese

Testcase: PR1
        
Build driver: 200212181304 Stable Build (M4) for Motif
      200212181304 Stable Build (M4) for GTK

OS: RedHat 8.0

JRE Version: J2RE 1.3.1 IBM build cxia32131-20021102 (JIT enabled: jitc)
     J2RE 1.4.0 IBM build cxia32140-20020917a (JIT enabled:jitc))
   
          
Summary: Path variable name can not contains GB18030 character in Eclipse for 
Linux. The environment includes: Eclipse for GTK(with JRE 1.3.1 and JRE 1.4.0)
column8:
Eclipse for Motif(with JRE 1.3.1).

Steps to recreate problem:
 1.click workbench-->preference  menu.
 2.select classpath variables item 
 3.click "New" button
column9:
the "New Variable Entry " window show up .
 4.input a variable name contains a GB18030 character. 
 5.select a file or folder contains a GB18030 character.
 6.click OK to add.

<<Error>>
 in the step 4
column10: when I input a GB18030 character
column11:
a labels 
shows "Invaild name ..." in the bottom of the window( as is shown in 
PR1_Mo.jpg). Can not continue.
 In the GTK version
column12: the inputted characters shows correctly
column13: and in \nthe Motif version
column14:
the inputted characters shows incorrectly(as is shown in 
PR1_mo.jpg)

<<Expected Result>>
 the class variable is added correctly.

Comments
 In the Eclipse for Motif (with JRE 1.4)
column15: this function is correctly.'

column7:
b'Minor enhancement suggestion: It would be nice to have the option of minimizing 
Eclipse to the system tray (running on Windows of course... I'm not sure if 
Linux has this capability) rather than to the taskbar.  I usually have Eclipse 
open all day on my desktop but frequently minimize it while I'm working on 
other tasks
column8:
minimizing to the system tray would help free up some of the 
limited real estate on the task bar.

There may also be a benefit of introducing a "pre-initialization" feature in 
Eclipse that would allow Eclipse to be started up at system launch and 
automatically minimized to the system tray (just like Mozilla).  When I want to 
launch Eclipse
column9: I simply double click on the system tray icon and things start \nup a whole lot faster.'

b'Found using WSWB 3.0 M8 driver + Eclipse Hyades 3.0 20040309_1448 driver.

Steps to reproduce:
-------------------
1. Start Eclipse.
2. Open the Profiling and Logging perspective.
3. Select Run -> Profile...
4. Double click on External Java Application to create a new configuration.
5. On the right hand side
column8: click on the Profiling tab.\n6. In the section labelled "Select a profiling set:"
column9: select "Memory Analysis".\n7. Click on the Close button to close this dialog. When you are prompted to sve \nchanges
column10:
select NO.
8. Select Run -> Profile...
9. Select the configuration that was just created earlier.
10. On the right hand side
column11: click on the Profiling tab.\n\nWhen I do that
column12: the two "tables" seems to look very different
column13: like there were \nproblems generating those two widgets. If you try to resize the dialog box
column14: \nEclipse will freeze
column15: then crash
column16: giving a JVM Terminated message.'

column7: b'In the ViewForm
column8:
the controls topXXX are given a y pos that is off by one pixel.

I believe the problem is in getClientArea().  There is magic number 1 when 
calculating y.

patch to follow.

-m@'

Rational Application Developer (RAD)

Build:

Present in 6.0 GM and later

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Import the Faces Client Sample
Help->Samples Gallery->application samples->web->faces samples->client

2. Right click portfolioJSF.jsp and run on server


Actual Results:

Flash Graph component on second tabbedPanel is not shown.
In the second pane of the second tabbedPanel
column9:
if the webservice is used (which
uses flash) this causes RAD to crash with a JVM termination

Expected Results:

The graph should be rendered correctly and the webservice return the share 
price.

Additional Information:

The problem seems to be with the internal browser being launched from the run 
on
server command. If the internal browser is launched via a button on the toolbar
in rad the pages work as expected.'

column7: b'Create a report design with a table that has contents in its cells.\nExport the design to a library
column8: so they have the same contents.\n\nIn the Outline of the report design
column9:
perform the following steps:
* Select the table: The whole table is highlighted. The Property Editor displays the table properties.
* Expand the Detail node. Select a Row. The row is highlighted. The Property Editor displays the row properties.
* Expand the Row. Select a Cell. The cell is highlighted. The Property Editor displays the cell properties.
* Expand the Cell. Select a report item in the cell. The report item is highlighted. The Property Editor displays the report item properties.
* Select the Cell again. The cell is highlighted. The Property Editor displays the cell properties.
* Select the Row again. The row is highlighted. The Property Editor displays the row properties.

Now
column10: open the library.\nIn the Outline of the library
column11:
perform the following steps:
* Select the table: The whole table is highlighted. The Property Editor displays table properties.
* Expand the Detail node. Select a Row. The row is highlighted. The Property Editor displays row properties.
* Expand the Row. Select a Cell. The cell is highlighted. The Property Editor displays cell properties.
* Expand the Cell. Select a report item in the cell. The layout shows only the report item
column12: not the whole table. The Property Editor displays the report item properties.\n* Select the Cell again. The layout shows only the report item
column13: not the whole table. The Property Editor displays the cell properties.\n* Select the Row again. The layout shows only the report item
column14:
not the whole table. The Property Editor displays row properties.

Expected:
In a library
column15: when selecting items inside a container such as a table
column16: the layout should show the whole container and highlight the selected component.'

b'Certain COSMOS projects contain library/jar-file references that are local to some developer's private environment. These should be removed and replaced by some classpath variables instead (or include the library and check it in).

E.g. project org.eclipse.cosmos.dr.drs.service.handler has a classpath reference to "D:/development/apache-tomcat-5.5.20/webapps/COSMOSUI/WEB-INF/lib/muse-complete-2.2.0.jar".
On my system I couldn't reproduce that path even if I wanted
column8:
since I have no D-drive...

I suggest to define an eclipse classpath variable "MUSE" or "MUSE_COMPLETE" or such and have the user point that to the location where he/she installed or downloaded muse.

Along similar lines: project "org.eclipse.cosmos.dc.spec" has a dependency on project "org.eclipse.cosmos-tests" because" because of the same library (apparently to be found in "data-collection/org.eclipse.cosmos.dc.tests/lib". I 'ld say that "non-test" projects should never have a reference into a "tests"-project.

Michael'

column7:
b'Update MDR framework to accept CMDBf query and registration requests in vanilla web service SOAP envelop formats.  
The request may not contain a WSA header.  
The body of the SOAP message does not contain elements for MUSE.  e.g. The wrapping elements for the MUSE operation and parameter 

This enhancement is important for interaction with non-COSMOS MDRs and clients.'
b"Brokers need to manage the addresses of MDRs that don't support WSA and WSRF."

b'The WSDL file from the CMDBf standard references the schema file using an http URL.  The proposed change is to reference a local copy of the schema file instead of the remote copy because problems has reported by CA dereferencing the schema due to network issues.  \n\nThis change will affect the toolkit
column8: which will need to copy an extra file to the META-INF directory
column9: and import statement of the WSDL file to be copied also need to change.'

b'Rational Application Developer v6.0

We have the "build automatically" feature is off (we build our projects 
whenever we'd like to... the automatic build sometimes is kind of annoying).

I will include an EAR file that you guys can import into the RAD workspace to 
reproduce the problem. It contains two projects: BuildTestEAR and BuildTestWEB. 
You can use the BuildTestWEB project to reproduce the problem described below.

The following works as expected when the project has just a WEB nature (does 
not have ASPECTJ nature):

If there are compilation errors in a project
column8: and then you select that project
column9: \nand "clean" the selected project (Project->Clean..)
column10: all compilation errors for \nthat project dissapear. The output folder is cleaned (in this case
column11:
the classes 
folder under the web-inf folder). The output folder is cleaned whenever you 
select to clean a project (regardless of having compilation errors or not).

However
column12: if you convert the BuildTestWEB project to ASPECT nature
column13:
then above 
functionality is lost:

If there are compilation errors in a project
column14: and then you select that project
column15: \nand "clean" the selected project (Project->Clean..)
column16:
compilation errors DO NOT 
dissapear for that project. The output folder is NOT cleaned when you select to 
clean a project (regardless of having compilation errors or not); files are not 
deleted.'

column7: b'I tried to write a little test to check that all bundles (IUs) had a correct "Provider Name". This basically just uses \n\niu.getProperty(IInstallableUnit.PROP_PROVIDER
column8: null);\n\nSome errors were expected
column9: but I discovered more than I expected
column10: and some were surprising. Upon investigation
column11: it appears those bundles that use the "OSGi standard default" method of localization do not have their values published in metadata
column12: only the "key". \n\nAs one example from Orbit
column13:
javax.xml.bind (version 2.2) uses this OSGi default method and the content.xml has (only)

<property name='org.eclipse.equinox.p2.name' value='%Bundle-Name.0'/>
<property name='org.eclipse.equinox.p2.provider' value='%Bundle-Vendor.0'/>

In contrast
column14:
a bundle using the old fashioned non standard method has 

<property name='df_LT.providerName' value='Eclipse.org'/>
<property name='df_LT.pluginName' value='Apache Batik AWT Utilities'/>
<property name='org.eclipse.equinox.p2.name' value='%pluginName'/>
<property name='org.eclipse.equinox.p2.provider' value='%providerName'/>
<property name='org.eclipse.equinox.p2.bundle.localization' value='plugin'/>

I understand only about 20% of what's going on here
column15: but seems odd that you can not get the "English" version of name or provider name
column16: if the OSGi standard default method is used
column17: but that you could if a non standard
column19: method was used. \n\nIn Orbit we are using "old" code to create the metdata (M4ish) but I\'ve seen the same thing in WTP using M6ish code. I searched bugzilla
column20: but didn\'t see anything reported or fixed that appeared related. \n\nAm I seeing something wrong? Or is this a bug in the "p2 publisher"?'

column7: b'There are existing OSLC clients and servers that implemented OSLC 1.0. When OSLC 2.0 was developed
column8: these clients and servers updated to OSLC 2.0
column9: but for backward compatibility
column10: continued to support OSLC 1.0. OSLC 2.0 introduced the OSLC-Core-Version header to identify the OSLC version. Some clients and servers (e.g.
column11: RDNG and RTC) default to OSLC 1.0 because when it was implemented
column12: the OSLC-Core-Version header did not exist. \n\nIn order to use clients and servers created with the Toolchain modeler and code generator with these applications
column13:
the services need to set the OSLC-Core-Version header to 2.0 in all HTTP responses. 

Specifically:
1. in <app>Constants.java
column14:
add:
    public static final String OSLC_VERSION_V2 = "2.0";

2. in the *Service. java file (the file that implements the OSLC REST services)

2.1. for PUT
column15: and DELETE
column16:
change:
return Response.ok().build();
to:
return Response.created(newResource.getAbout()).entity(aResource).header(CE4IoTConnectorConstants.HDR_OSLC_VERSION
column17: CE4IoTConnectorConstants.OSLC_VERSION_V2).build();\n\n2.2. for POST (create)
column19: CE4IoTConnectorConstants.OSLC_VERSION_V2).build();\n\n2.3. for GET
column20: add the following right before the resource is returned:\nhttpServletResponse.addHeader(CE4IoTConnectorConstants.HDR_OSLC_VERSION

b'I noticed that files changed this calendar year by the build team
column8: such as feature.xml in features
column9:
still contains the copyright "Copyright (c) 2007 IBM Corporation and others.  All rights reserved."

There are two problems:

1. If a file was changed in 2008
column10: this year should be added to the copyright so that it says "2007
column11: 2008".  The syntax is "<creationYear>
column12:
<lastModifiedYear>".

2. Files that have only been touched by IBM committers should not contain the phrase "and others".  

One example that demonstrates both problems is the feature.xml file for org.eclipse.cosmos.dc.  In that case
column13: the copyright should be:\n"Copyright (c) 2007
column14: 2008 IBM Corporation.  All rights reserved."\n\nPlease take a pass through files owned by the build team and make appropriate corrections.'

column7: b"The org.eclipse.cosmos.dc.cmdbf.services plug-in is supposed to be packaged as 6 modules (jar files).  The latest build has that plug-in packaged as a single osgi bundle.  This breaks the code that loads resources using the class loader
column8: and also the design that only the jars needed by an adopter will be needed on the path.  Also
column9: the JUnits cannot compile because they can't see the classes in the bundle.  The current weekly integration build is broken."

column7: b'We should either include the source code with our downloads
column8: or provide alternate zips that include full source.  The reason is that a common scenario would be for someone to install our SDK into Eclipse and attempt to develop an MDR.  If they are debugging their code and stepping into our classes
column9: they will see no source if they installed from the download zips instead of checking out projects from Eclipse.'

column7: b'The last time the cmdbf.services plugin was updated in the build was 2/5/08.  So any code changes since that time have not been included in the build.  One example of such a change that was not built is bug 219908.  We need to figure out ASAP why this is happening
column8: since we need to make sure the latest code is made available for this key plugin.'

column7: b'The download page does indicate WTP as a dependency.  \n\nWe need to add a link to download WTP on the download page and indicate WTP is required for COSMOS SDK.'

column9: there should be 21 jar files in this lib directory.'

I browse to the directory where I saved my file and I can't see it.

I think the following should be done.

programs provide this."

column7: b'Create patch is missing tonnes of mnemonics.'

b'Recently JDT compiler\'s Main.java and relevant area were generified after we discovered that there was a potential for wrong types being mised in a raw type collection. Tycho should adjust their code too.\n\nSpecifically
column8: in the past
column9: clients can call handleEndorseddirs(List<String> list) with a List<String> and expect that when the method returns
column10: list will contain objects of type FileSystem.Classpath. Needless to say
column11: this approach was bad.\n\nAfter the fix and after the recent upgrade to the compiler
column13: new File(javaHome
column15: we never encountered -endorsed option. This must be fixed immediately as this will impact the Java 9 work.'

column7: b'Using the 0214 driver
column8:
JDIDebugModel.createMethodBreakpoint was called with 
entry set to true and exit set to false.  However suspend events are being sent 
both on entry to and exit from the method.  I did not see this problem with the 
0129 driver.

This seems to be what is happening in JDT:
After the JavaMethodBreakpoint is created its handleEvent method gets called for 
a class prepare event.  It then calls handleClassPrepareEvent which calls both 
createMethodEntryRequest and createMethodExitRequest.  When the exit request is 
hit handleEvent is called again which now calls handleBreakpointEvent.  This 
calls handleMethodEvent which does not check whether the breakpoint was really 
an exit breakpoint.

I also noticed in createMethodRequest the following line:

request.setEnabled(isEnabled() && (isExit() || isEntry()))'

column7:
b'External tool configurations and external tool project builders from version
2.0 and 2.1 need to be migrated to launch configurations.

External tool configurations
column8: stored in the metadata as externaltools.xml (2.0)\nor .xtools/*.xtool (2.1)
column9:
can be moved to launch configurations that reside in
the metadata. I believe we can do this essentially at startup.

External tool project builders should be interpreted as configurations at
runtime
column10:
and stored as configurations only when they are edited. This should
allow people who want to share a project between users on Eclipse 2.0 and
Eclipse 2.1 to coexist. We should also consider prompting the user before
converting the builders and explaining that they will not be compatible with
older versions of Eclipse if they are edited.'

b'Build 20030221\n\n1. Using the New Class wizard
column8:
create a class called "Grah" with a main method.
2. Delete the auto-inserted comments and JavaDoc preceding the class
declaration.
3. Inside the main method
column9: type "std" and hit Ctrl+space.\n4. Since the std template was recently removed (I keep forgetting)
column10:
a reference
to StdAppletViewerFactory and an import will be inserted.
5. Say "Gah!" and hit Ctrl+z to remove the results of the code assist.

reference and the import remain.
7. Hit Ctrl+z a couple more times. The JavaDoc and comments return but the
reference and import remain.

I'll attach screenshots showing the progression of the file contents.'

b'Since Mylar has a policy of ensuring no manual preference configuration on install
column8: we have a wizard that automatically sets our proposal computers as the default.  However
column9: this currently involves the hack of duplicating the current preference functionality (code is below).  \n\n1) Would it be possible to expose this proposal computer inclusion setting preference page behavior to avoid the duplication (internally for now
column10: perhaps candidate for API later)?\n\n2) If not
column11: what is the mechanism to ensure that the new proposal computers are registered with existing editors?  Currently the code below doesn\'t register them until restart
column12:
but changing the settings in the prefs page take effect immediately.

-------------------------
public static void installContentAssist(IPreferenceStore javaPrefs
column13: boolean mylarContentAssist) {\n String oldValue = javaPrefs.getString(PreferenceConstants.CODEASSIST_EXCLUDED_CATEGORIES);\n StringTokenizer tokenizer = new StringTokenizer(oldValue
column16: newValue);\n }'

column7:
b'Build 20030206

1. Help / About Eclipse Platform
2. Press Feature Details

Feature name: "Eclipse Platform Plug-in Developer Resources"
Blurb shows: "Eclipse Platform SDK"

Feature name: "Eclipse Platform Plug-in Developer Resources (Windows)"
Blurb shows: "Eclipse Platform SDK (Windows)"

These should be made consistent. The blurb should say 
"...Plug-in Developer Resources...".'

b"We are developing a wizard using the WizardNewProjectCreationPage to create a
new project for an existing J2EE app. The output directory for the app can
contain class and jar files from other sources - outside this app. When we
create the project
column8: Eclipse removes the contents. I realize this is reported in\nbug 20042 as well
column9:
but my question is why am I not seeing this same behavior on
Linux? Would this not be happening on both OS's if in fact it was based on an
Eclipse mandate?

The removal seems to be happening in:
org.eclipse.jdt.internal.ui.wizards.buildpaths.BuildPathsBlock in the method:
internalConfigureJavaProject.

Can someone comment on how it differs on Linux and if there are any plans to
make this a configurable feature of the New Project capabilities?"

b'Checkout deletes the project before checking out!!! This is very bad; you can no\nlonger create a Java project and check out over top of it. We should delete the\ncontents
column8: not the project itself. Must fix before next integration build.'

column7:
b"Basic idea is to specify issue description and/or some keywords that could be used to run bugzilla query and allow user to review results before submitting new issue.

From https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=104100#c9

You might want to have a look at what the KDE project did to bugzilla --
basically a PHP frontend that guides bugreporters in a wizard-like manner to
submit better reports.

To avoid as many dupes as possible
column8:
the reporter needs to enter some keywords
(typically the summary line) with which a bug database search is performed.

The reporter is presented the results and is asked to look for reports that
look like his own problem.

If he finds one
column9:
he usually adds a comment to that bugreport and adds himself
to the CC list.

If he doesn't he can go on and submit a new one.

That process helped tremendously in preventing dupes.

To see it in action
column10: visit http://bugs.kde.org -- you need to create an account\nto access the reporting wizard
column11: though."

column7: b'There are really three interesting locations for bundles and their data in a running Eclipse. Install - This is where the files were laid down on disk. There can be many install locations but ideally there would be only one copy of each bundle/plugin. Install locations may also be server based and contain massive numbers of bundles shared by many different users. Configuration - configurations express a subset of the plugins available from all known install locations. They represent a coherent set of function for a particular user or usecase. So a user might choose to have an IDE configuration containing Java and Web tooling and a "productivity" configuration contianing mail
column8: IM
column9: calendaring
column10: word processing
column11:
... plugins.  
The user then runs these different configurations independently in separate 
VMs.  Allowing parameterization etc at the configuration level allows 
configuration designers (e.g.
column12: users) to override installation defaults and in \neffect
column13: create their own customized installs. Instance - A running configuration may have further needs for parameterization
column14:
preferences and metadata.  Configurations can be run on many 
different instance datasets.

To the extent possible
column15: the runtime should minimize the copying and duplication \nof data on disk.  Current products can exceed 1GB in install size so any \ncopying strategy will quickly run into difficulty.  In particular
column16:
the OSGi 
framework cannot assume that it will own or control the install location of a 
bundle.  It should be happy to be told where the bundle is.  

Further
column17: as an optimization
column18:
it should not assume that the bundle is in a jar 
file but rather must allow for bundles to be unjar'd into the filesystem.  
Running in this mode it should be able to assume that any extraction of natives 
and other files (e.g.
column19:
nested jars) will have been done by some install 
mechanism.

BundleContext.getDataFile() provides access to what is effectively the 
configuration data area.  multiple instances of the same configuration would 
(erroneously) share this data area for their instance data.

One workaround is to have a 1:1 correspondence between configurations and 
instances.  This is what the current Eclipse does but it causes no end of 
difficulty.  Rather
column20:
the proposal is to have the Eclipse runtime continue to 
provide its metadata services for the instances.  This would continue to be 
held in the location spec by -data on the command line or user.dir.  The OSGi 
framework metadata location is largely uninteresting.'

column7: b'PDE is building the tooling for bundles
column8:
and we need to get these things straight.

File name: extensions.xml
Root element: bundle
column9: no attributes should be processed. \nChildren: either extension-point or extension elements
column10: as they exist today in\nEclipse.'

column7: b'In a set up where only boot is loaded into the workspace
column8: OSGiBootLoader is not \nable to find the osgi folder because it assumes this one is also loaded from in \nthe workspace.'

column7: b'The search method of the EclipseStarter does not find org.eclipse.osgi.services \nnor any other bundles specified on the osgi.bundles list because it does not \nlook for folders with version numbers at the end.'

b'Diagnosing exceptions thrown by OSGi is difficult because the nested exception\nis not printed. Consider overriding BundleException.printStackTrace to also\nprint the nested exception.  See Eclipse runtime CoreException for an example.'
b'In case where a bundle is shipped with a manifest.mf and a plugin.xml
column8: \nmodifications in the plugin.xml will not be detected by the osgi layer (this \nexpected since the fwk only cares about manifest.mf)
column9: nor by the registry layer.\n\nIndeed
column10: the registry layer should take care of this case and verify if the \nplugin.xml has changed or not. Doing that is ok
column11:
but it penalizes the user with 
a timestamp check only for the convenience of developer.

One solution could consist in only running this check when running with -dev.'

column8: an entity from B can be renamed at its point of use in A

column10: even though it is fixed-form (so it will eliminate all comments and whitespace from B).'

b'Created attachment 137382 [details]
program.f90

From e-mail ("Some Photran issues" 4/29/09):

It seems I found a situation
column8: when VPG does not link a definition and a reference to it. If you take a look at the attached files and the constructed VPG database
column9: you\'ll notice that in file "Subroutines1.f90" in expression "MyArray2(DIM - 3) = 0.1" the reference to "DIM"
column10: which is declared as a constant in module "Mod1"
column11: is not linked to its definition.'

column7: b'From e-mail ("Re: Workspace & updated file" 4/7/09):\n\nWhen I start my program transformation I see many warnings that a particular include file could not be found
column8: though I made sure that it is present in the project\'s folder. But this did not result in any problems so far.\n\nI noticed another problematic issue. In the attached files I reproduced the problematic part. Subroutine "morton_neighbors" receives an argument "ndim" and uses module "physicaldata"
column9: which uses another module - "paramesh_dimensions". Module "paramesh_dimensions" declares a constant
column10: which has the same name as the argument of the subroutine - "ndim". Constant "ndim" from the module "paramesh_dimensions" does not conflict with the argument "ndim" of the subroutine "morton_neighbors"
column11: because of the "private" declaration in the module "physicaldata"
column12: which makes all entities (variables
column13: subprograms) of this module (including those from the used modules) to have private visibility by default. So
column14: this code can be successfully compiled (but if we remove "private" declaration from the module "physicaldata"
column15: the compiler will complain about an ambiguous reference to "ndim" in the subroutine "morton_neighbors"). \n\nThe problem is the following: when my code tries to get definitions for a reference to "ndim" inside the subroutine "morton_neighbors"
column16: it gets both definitions - from the subroutine and from the module "paramesh_dimensions"
column17: and this results in an exception. It seems that only one definition should be associated with the reference of "ndim" inside the subroutine - the definition from the subroutine.\n\nAtt (FLASH): paramesh_dimensions.f90 physicaldata.f90 subroutine.f90'

http://wiki.eclipse.org/PTP/photran/documentation/photran6

Photran 6 Advanced Features
http://wiki.eclipse.org/PTP/photran/documentation/photran6advanced

Topics in the (basic) User's Guide should include:
(1) what the C preprocessor allows (#include
column8: #define
column9: #ifdef
column10: __LINE__
column11:
__FILE__etc.)
(2) how Photran decides what files are C preprocessed (content types/filename extensions) and how to change this
(3) how to set C preprocessor include paths
(4) how to set predefined macros

The Advanced Features manual should note which features do not (yet) work on C preprocessed code (refactorings) and which ones do (the others)."

column7: b'In the advanced features manual
column8: these categories are marked TODO.  They should be completed before the Helios release.'

column7: b"The JUnit test runner pops up the Photran welcome page (since the workspace is cleared) when Photran is installed and it runs a test suite other than Photran's.\n\nThe page is purposely not displayed when Photran is in testing mode (environment variable TESTING is set)
column8: but this is not the case when a test suite other than Photran's is run."

column7: b'The documentation for Photran 6 still has some items marked TODO (most importantly
column8: the section on upgrading projects from Photran 5).\n\nAlso
column9: the installation instructions contain some outdated version information.'

column7: b"Three strings for the various Fortran source forms were externalized to bundle.properties
column8:
but they are being looked for in plugin.properties instead (and are not found).  This problem affects 6.0 RC4.  This means that the Outline view and the Source Forms property page display incorrectly.  See attached screenshots.

This is a serious regression because

* every user will see this bug.  It is apparent every time the Outline view is open and every time the Source Forms property page is opened.

* Source Form properties must be set for every Photran project
column9: including projects upgrading from Photran 5
column10: so the Source Forms property page is critical for the 6.0 release.\n\n* the externalized names that are displayed instead (%source-form.name.1
column11:
%source-form.name.2) do not adequately describe the intent.  This is a very serious usability problem.

The fix is technically very simple (move the externalized strings into plugin.properties) and should have no impact on other projects in the Helios train.

As for why this bug was not discovered until now
column12: (1) those strings were externalized just prior to RC4 (not having them externalized was a bug in itself)
column13: and (2) this bug only appeared in the RC4 build; the externalized strings work correctly in the runtime workspace
column14: for reasons I don't completely understand."

column7:
b'Created attachment 184567 [details]
Patch including all updated projects for this enhancement.

Added and modified classes in order to implement IF statement to IF construct and IF construct to IF statement refactoring to Photran. Program will validate that a valid IF statement or construct is selected at the time of refactoring
column8: and will ensure that the selected text is refactorable.'

column7:
b'Created attachment 184839 [details]
Patch file created against CVS @ 6:55PMCST 2010-12-8

This refactoring will
\xe2\x80\xa2 Replace instances of ASSIGN statements with assignment statements.
\xe2\x80\xa2 Replace assigned GOTO statements with SELECT CASE statements with nested (normal) GOTOs.
Refactoring of a particular ASSIGN or assigned GOTO will fail if
\xe2\x80\xa2 The statement label used in an ASSIGN is not present in the scoping unit of the ASSIGN statement.
\xe2\x80\xa2 The variable name associated with the ASSIGN statement is used in an action statement.
The user will be presented with a graphical interface to select if a default CASE statement should be added to the SELECT CASE in the refactored output.
If multiple variables are specified by assign statements
\xe2\x80\xa2 If all of the labels are used in action statements
column8: the refactoring will fail\n\xe2\x80\xa2 If some of the labels are used in an action statement
column9: the user will be prompted to decide if the refactoring should continue refactoring only the cases where the variable is not used in an action statement.\n\nA hot key is added to launch the refactoring.  The hot key is assigned to Alt+Shift+A.'

column7:
b'Created attachment 185105 [details]
Remove Obsolete Language Features - Refactoring Enhancement (Patch)

This enhancement request contains the code for 3 additional "Remove Obsolete Language Feature" refactorings for the Photran editor. The included path file contains the code for the implemented features as well as automated tests for their behavior. 

The 3 refactorings are:
1) Removing Branches to END IF Statements
2) Removing Real and Double Precision DO Loop Counters
3) Removing PAUSE Statements


More details about the refactorings and their implementation can be found on our development wiki here: https://agora.cs.illinois.edu/display/cs427fa10/AvocadoChestnut



Affected files from original Photran Installation are:

\xe2\x80\xa2 org.eclipse.photran.core.vpg Package \xe2\x80\x93 Core refactoring code.
- src/org/eclipse/phoran/internal/core/refactoring Directory

RemoveBranchToEndIfRefactoring.java
RemovePauseStmtRefactoring.java
RemoveRealAndDoublePrecisionLoopCountersRefactoring.java
Messages.java
- src/org/eclipse/phoran/internal/core/refactoring/infrastructure Directory

FortranResourceRefactoring.java


\xe2\x80\xa2 org.eclipse.photran.core.vpg.tests Package \xe2\x80\x93 Refactoring test suite and test cases. (test cases in directories now shown.)
- src/org/eclipse/phoran/internal/tests/refactoring Directory

RemoveBranchToEndIfTestSuite.java
RemovePauseStmtTestSuite.java
RemoveRealandDoublePrecisionLoopCountersTestSuite.java

- refactoring-test-code Directory

remove-branch-to-end-if Directory
remove-pause-stmt Directory
remove-real-and-double-precision-loop-counters Directory
org.eclipse.photran.ui.vpg Package \xe2\x80\x93 Contains GUI messages and menu extensions for refactorings. 

- src/org.eclipse.photran.internal.ui.refactoring Directory

plugin.xml 
RemoveRealAndDoublePrecisionLoopCounterInputPage.java
Messages.java
Message.properties'

Create a local C project  from the new project wizard "helloMPI".

column8:
"Refactor" gives only what looks like must be Photran choices.
Actually the same is true of the refactor menu on the local project as well.

The Refactor Menu at the top has the Rename choice greyed out as well. 

Well.. upon further investigation
column9: a straight CDT eclipse (no PTP
column10:

And of course now I noticed that there is a "Rename..." choice right there on the Context menu.  So that is what I should have used to begin with.

So my question is...  if it's not hijacking
column11: it\'s at the least confusing.\nShould the menu be disabled if it\'s not Fortran code that\'s being selected?\nOr if it\'s not a Fortran project?  Or am I making a mountain out of a molehill?'

b"Build 20020205

I have experienced severely slow shutdown times with the latest build.  I added 
some tracing in the plugin registry shutdown
column8:
and found that shutting down the 
jdt.core plugin is the culprit. 

Test case:

1) Open a brand new workbench
2) Create a java project
3) Immediately shutdown

The following trace information is displayed:

Shutting down plugin: org.eclipse.jdt.core
Finished plugin shutdown for org.eclipse.jdt.core time: 311869ms

That's over 5 minutes!  I hope to make these trace options available in a build 
soon.  In this case it looks like it was indexing rt.jar
column9: and the shutdown() \nmethod was waiting on the index manager thread."

b"Build Identifier: 2.0.0.201204020613 (Nightly)\n\ngit stash apply doesn't detect conflict
column8:
uses version from stash

Reproducible: Always

Steps to Reproduce:
Create a conflict situation.
   Example:
     1) git reset --hard HEAD~1 (from History view)
     2) make a change to the same file and line as previous HEAD commit
     3) git stash (from Git Repository view)
     4) git reset --hard <previous head> (from History view)
     5) git stash apply (from Git Repository view)

The file from the stash is used
column9: and no conflict is marked.\n\nNote: this is inconsistent with the command-line behavior (which marks a conflict)."

column7:
b'Steps to reproduce:
* Create any file with UNIX line endings that is EXACTLY 8000 bytes in size.
* Check it into repository using Git or EGit
* Set option "core.autocrlf = true" in EGit (this is the recommended default if Git for Windows is installed and EGit will inherit it)
* Delete the file in your workspace
* Do a reset --hard in EGit

Problem:
The file checks out as 0 bytes in size and instantly shows up as modified in the staging area. I was able to reproduce this on several PCs with different Java
column8: Eclipse and EGit versions. Files with 7999 or 8001 bytes check out fine. This might also be a JGit bug
column9: not sure.'

column7: b'In order to integrate the STS with IdAS

column7: b'See mail thread\nThere are no methods yet for creating property/attribute/metadata values.'
b'See mail thread\nwe need bring consistency to the behavior of the various create*() methods.  Some will create an instance of an interface
column8: and then the caller is required to call some add() method to put it into the store.  Others will return the created object and add it to the store at the same time.\n \nI think there was a proposal once to make the default behavior to only return the created object and require a subsequent add
column9: but include another param (boolean add) to the create methods such that the create and add could happen at once.'
